story:
Why an audiobook?

One afternoon I was talking with Pa'B (a name that all of Bill's grandchildren call him) about all of the interesting audiobooks I was listening to. He was not at all familiar with books in audio form so he was asking all sorts of questions about the medium. The conversation eventually turned to his books and how difficult it was now days to get a book published by a publishing house. By the end of our conversation, I could see a sparkle in his eyes that was not there before.

The sparkle in his eyes motivated me to think this through - I thought to myself "I know people; I could bring one of his stories back to life, in a way he never imagined!"

Mission

Bill Stokes self published Ship the Kids on Ahead in 1968, before all to tools, such as the internet and amazon were available. The sales of this book were not great at all. I want to show to him that self publishing can be a viable option these days. On top of that I want to make his work available to a new generation of readers and listeners that crave well written stories.

Bill Stokes, my grandfather, has always given great advice. It is my goal to share his insight and advice to as many people as possible. How can I do this? Very simple, really. I plan to make his works available in modern digital formats for this generation and more to come! 

Who am I?

I am Paul Stokes, the grandson of Bill. I have admired my grandfather for years and am passionate about words and stories, but rarely have time to read so I turned to audiobooks. Audiobooks have played an important role in my life; in fact, I manage/own audiobookreviewer.com.

What is this book all about?

"Ship the Kids on Ahead" is a collection of short stories originally written by Bill Stokes. They appeared in his column in the Wisconsin State Journal titled "Stokes Pokes". "Ship the Kids on Ahead' was originally self published in 1968 by Bill.

These stories show a small slice of his life during the 1950's and 60's starring Bill, Betty (his wife) and their children: Larry, Patty, Ricky, Scotty and Mike. Bill shares personal occurrences in his life through humor, wit and genuine love.


Who is Bill Stokes?

Bill Stokes, Wisconsin's most famous outdoor writer.

Born in Barron, Wisconsin, on September 11, 1931, Bill Stokes grew up on a small dairy farm between Barron and Rice Lake. He began his official writing career as an outdoor writer and also a general reporter for the Stevens Point Daily Journal where he served as columnist, reporter and outdoor writer. In 1961 he moved to the Wisconsin State Journal, out of Madison, where he wrote outdoor and personal columns. Some of these writings from his columns appear in the book “Ship The Kids On Ahead.” In 1969, the Milwaukee Journal became his venue as a feature writer and columnist. In 1982 he found new ground to cover in 1982 at the Chicago Tribune. After 11 years at the Chicago Tribune, Bill decided to retire and pursue free-lance projects.

During his long journalism career, Bill won many conservation awards, including the Ernie Pyle Memorial Award from Scripps-Howard News Service in 1972! His work has appeared in many national publications; to name a few: Readers Digest, Outdoor Life and Sports Afield. He has compiled three anthologies of his newspaper writing and has authored two children’s books.

His writing, his perspective on life and his passion makes him a masterful story teller. His ability to tell the story and make the connection with his readers is uncanny; taking him to audio with one of the voice professionals below will only enhance the listeners enjoyment.

Bill is also a veteran of the Korean War where he fought as an infantryman for the US Army.

Bill is in the process of publishing his latest novel. One fan had this to say:

Bill writes with good humor and feeling. His descriptions make his readers think about their own personal lives and put their feelings toward their fellow men in proper perspective. -Warren P. Knowles, Governor of Wisconsin, 1965-1971

Sample Story

The Hammer Is In The Petunias
It WAS one of those “next week we’ve got to get organized” days that inspired me to pound peg board all over one end of the basement for neat and convenient storage of tools and such.
And it was something to behold—the hammer and the pliers and the saws reposing with an orderliness they had never before known. I sat for most of the rest of the day just admiring how beautiful it was.
Then sometime the next forenoon my wife needed a nail driven into a closet wall; and it was pure joy to walk down to the basement knowing that the hammer was in its place just waiting for some hammering. No more frantic searching, no more finding the kids to question them about the hammer whereabouts. “I would be delighted to drive that nail for you,” I told Betty. “I will get my trusty hammer off its hook, and I will drive it for you right this very minute.”
I remember I even whistled as I walked down the stairs. Then I reached for the hammer, and, as unbelievable as it may seem, the hammer was not there. We have been robbed, I thought, remembering the stem lecture the family had been given about putting things back in their rightful peg-board places.
“Where’s the hammer?” I shouted.
“Larry had it,” Scotty said.
“Ricky had it,” Larry said.
“Scotty had it," Ricky said.
“I didn’t have it,” Mike said.
I found it in the petunia patch where it had been used to crack a walnut that had been snitched out of the kitchen.
Why not, I asked myself, just store the hammer in the petunia patch?
And so that is how it is. The hammer can most generally be located among the petunias, albeit a bit rusty, but serviceable nonetheless.
The hammer was followed by the pliers in the move to what I call natural storage. The pliers are kept under the cookbooks in a kitchen drawer. The saw hangs in the treehouse.
Betty’s sewing basket is where we find the screwdriver. The best place to look for the wrenches is out in the garage between the garbage cans where bicycle repair is most often done.
And the peg-board hooks? Well, the use varies, but they are used for: a broken cap pistol, a tom cowboy shirt, the wheels from a toy tank, an old picture of Batman, and other things of this nature.
Are we organized? We are indeed. This very second I can tell you that the bathroom plunger is out under the hedge. If that isn’t organization, I’d like to know what is?
© Bill Stokes
All rights reserved.

Narrators

Stefan Rudnicki
Named the Golden Voice of Science Fiction by Audiofile Magazine, Stefan Rudnicki has produced over 3000 audiobooks and voiced over 500. He is the voice of Ender Wiggin in Orson Scott Card’s Ender’s Game Series, and Col. Graff in the full-cast version Ender’s Game Alive. He is Matt Helm® in Donald Hamilton’s series, and Quarry in Max Allan Collins' novels.

Sean Runnette
Sean Runnette has stepped up to be the Producer of this project. He has earned two Audie nominations and five Earphones Awards for his narration. He has also directed and produced more than 200 audiobooks including several Audie Award winners. He has toured the US and internationally with The American Repertory Theater and Mabou Mines, as well as appearing in Two if by Sea, Copland, Sex and the City, Law and Order and 3rd Watch. He lives, unapologetically, in New Jersey.

RC Bray
Audie Award (think and Oscar for audiobooks) winning narrator who was the first to bring The Martian to life. Self-published in 2011 by its author, Andy Weir, THE MARTIAN is a bestselling and critically acclaimed first novel that puts readers inside the mind of an astronaut stranded on Mars. The book was bought by a publisher and reissued last year. A movie adaptation, starring Matt Damon, was a box office hit.

Xe Sands
With numerous AudioFile Earphones Awards and nearly 200 audiobooks to her credit so far, Xe Sands (that’s pronounced “Ex-ee”) is known for her ability to make an audiobook an intimate experience for her listeners. Interestingly, Sands didn’t come to audiobooks through acting as most narrators do. She began her adult life as a visual artist. “I used to paint. I did a lot of photo manipulation, and just a whole bunch of handcrafting of all kinds.” How did she get involved in the audio world? “My daughter and I had a long commute for many years, and we went through a million audiobooks.” She also read aloud to her daughter, until it dawned on her: “I would love to do that.” She didn’t think her voice would be one that anyone would want to hear, but she really wanted to try her hand at narration. So in 2008, she discovered a supportive audio community that encouraged recording. She worked with them for a few years before she was “discovered.”

Joe Hempel
Joe Hempel is an Ironman 70.3 triathlete who is on the fast track to becoming one of the go to narrators after just being in the business a short time. Most known as the voice of Gary Jonas's Jonathan Shade he's also known for his AI and Sci-Fi prowess with books like the best selling Surviving AI by Calum Chace, Silicon Series by William Massa and the upcoming Game Changer by NYT Bestselling author Douglas E Richards.

James Foster
Nominated for three Society of Voice Arts and Sciences Voice Arts Awards in 2015 for best audiobook narration in the science-fiction, fantasy, and mystery categories. Many audiophiles will know him as the voice of Adrian from Adrian's Undead Diary written by Chris Philbrook.

Funds Breakdown

Audio, trade paperback and ebook production - 65%
Marketing - 20%
Indiegogo fees and perks - 15%

Stretch Goals

In $5,000 increments beyond the goal we will work on audio productions of other books by Bill Stokes.
OR
It will go towards a fishing trip for Bill.

Risks & Challenges

You may have to wait a bit longer than expected; sometimes audio takes longer to produce or life can happen in the lives of the voice professionals. Regardless, the books will happen! The narrators are already recording the stories. I hope we can count on you to help. This is one of those rare opportunities people never have - an opportunity to help both Bill and then others who need to hear the heartfelt moments Bill should share.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

If you cannot contribute please consider sharing this campaign with your friends, family via social media

story:
Summing it Up

Hi, my name is Joe Dell, and yes, I am an average Joe. Just a hard-working man with a few dreams. Telling stories has always been a passion of mine and I’m hoping you’ll join me on my journey and help me tell this story to the world.  

Fort Apollo tells of the story of five boys on the brink of adolescence; it follows them along their many adventures during the summer of 1969. This story follows the boys as they navigate the turbulent times at the end of the sixties in their own unique way. Their sense of adventure and imagination know no bounds and they get involved in one situation after another. Michael is the leader of this small band of friends, physically abused by his father and emotionally neglected by his mother. In a twist of fate a woman comes into his life. Sharon Gibbons has been exiled from her homeland in Ireland for a mistake that she will regret for the rest of her life, events so devastating it has caused her to lose her faith. Through Michael she meets Jim a decorated Vietnam veteran disillusioned since his return from war. He can't understand why he and his fellow veterans are treated so disrespectfully for simply serving their country. Can the three of them find a way to bury their pain and  and  begin to live a normal life? Sometimes life can be very hard.Broken souls,broken hearts and broken bones.

What I Need & What You Get

Like I said, I’m an average Joe. There are no special monuments in my name and I haven’t won the Pulitzer or any purple hearts. But you helping me reach my goal will allow me to complete this story which I have been working on and growing for over twenty years. In the past two years I have finally been able to put it all together. With your help, I’ll be able to write the story and get it published. Your contribution will help me put this story on paper, finally! It’ll help with editing costs, artwork, and publishing. This an amazing story! I know that is a bold statement, but I am going to back it up by letting you read the first chapter.

One of the things that I’m especially excited about is the local help that I’ve already received since moving to the Lehigh Valley in PA. Michael Kehs is a woodworking artist and he’s really pumped up to help me build the main character Michael’s skateboard to give to you as a perk. He’s also going to build the shingle shooter and slingshot!

Hannah Hess is an amazing local artist her painting of the book cover captures the innocence of the boys while the dark silhouettes at the bottom foreshadow conflicts to come. 

And finally, there’s Wendy Strain. She’s fantastic writer and editor that’s helping me bring the characters to life and put all of this together.

Are you ready for that first chapter?  Great! And just so you know, as the contributions grow, I won’t leave you hanging. Once this campaign hits $2000, I’ll tease chapter 2. Then at $3000, I’ll tease chapter 3 and at $6000, I’ll introduce you to chapter four. Even a small donation such as $5, $10, or $25 can go a long way to reaching my goal.

Check out chapter 1 here. I hope you enjoy it! Please feel free to give me some feedback, positive or negative, it’s all good! https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JqP6oGf6qwWBo4FfdjEFM4IbutMGzohM/view?usp=sharing

I will be setting up a Facebook page to tease chapters if I reach certain milestones. As soon as I have that set up, I’ll post it here for you to follow me on my endeavor.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Listen, I understand that not everyone can dig into their pockets but that’s not the only way that you can help. Please help me share my story. Tell people about my campaign and please help share it on social media. And don’t forget the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
My Story

I am a full-time writer for Consumer Media Network and a music and arts columnist for CultureMap Houston. I've written for the Houston Press, Option Magazine, and the contemporary classical music blog Sequenza 21.

I especially enjoy interviewing musicians from the world of jazz in all its forms and permutations. My column and personal blog has featured conversations with pianist Bobby Lyle, saxophonist Mindi Abair, singer Dee Dee Bridgewater, guitarist Russell Malone, conga maestro Poncho Sanchez, and New Orleans pianist Larry Sieberth, to name just a few. It was my conversation with Mindi Abair that sparked my idea to compile a collection of my interviews with women who play jazz in all of its forms. The working title of the book is Women in Jazz.

Some great musicians, including Mindi Abair, Jane Ira Bloom, Tia Fuller, and Pamela York have already agreed to be interviewed for the book. I plan to conduct at least 15 additional interviews for the book.

Does such a book currently exist? There are plenty of books about jazz featuring men, and it is a genre that, in spite of the groundbreaking advancements several notable women, is dominated by a male worldview. So what about the women composing for and directing big bands? Or shred with the best of them in the world of jazz-fusion? Or proudly play a kind of music that is a hybrid of styles and influences and called "jazz" just for the sake of a label?

What I Need

Right now I have just a few interviews archived, and just beginning to contact more artists to see if they're agreeable to my interviewing them for the book.

AS A FIRST STEP toward promoting the book project, building a community supportive of the concept, and connecting with potential interviewees, I want to create a short, six to seven minute, professional promotional video. The video will include audio excerpts from women I've already interviewed for the book, exclusive content from some of the interviewees publicists, and me describing the scope and timeline of the project. The video will be shot and edited by Jonathan Jindra, an extremely talented and gifted videographer whose work appears on his business website Binarium Productions.

The final cut will appear on a blog documenting the Women In Jazz project as it comes together. The blog will be regularly updated with news about the project and the participants, becoming a tool for promotion and future fundraising as well as a hub for people invested in jazz and the contributions of women to the music.

$1,000 will cover the costs of shooting and editing the video, which will include exclusive interview footage, creating special graphics, and crucially, for a video touting a project involving interviews with musicians, producing a professional soundtrack.

The Impact

“Chris wrote music reviews for me when I re-launched the music and culture magazine Option as an online-only publication in 2010. I found him extremely knowledgeable of music ranging from pop to the farthest reaches of the avant-garde. He is easy to communicate with, a solid writer and thinker, an entertaining read, and he has an edge on other music writers — Chris is a composer of experimental music himself.” — Mark Kemp, Editor-in-Chief at Creative Loafing Charlotte, former Senior Music Editor at Rolling Stone magazine

“Chris’ work as a writer is the kind readers search for. He provides a compelling story as well as a back history when needed, mixed with attention to detail and unique dialogue. Most recently in his coverage of Dave Koz and Poncho Sanchez, Chris delivered pieces full of appeal and substance. It’s obvious Chris does his research and puts forth a notable story.” — Kelly Johanns-DiCillo, Tour Publicist at Concord Music Group

(Upper right photo: Composer, bandleader and singer Sofia Rei; Main photo of Mindi Abair by Reisig & Taylor)

My Story
I am a full-time writer for Consumer Media Network and a music and arts columnist for CultureMap Houston. I've written for the Houston Press, Option Magazine, and the contemporary classical music blog Sequenza 21.
I especially enjoy interviewing musicians from the world of jazz in all its forms and permutations. My column and personal blog has featured conversations with pianist Bobby Lyle, saxophonist Mindi Abair, singer Dee Dee Bridgewater, guitarist Russell Malone, conga maestro Poncho Sanchez, and New Orleans pianist Larry Sieberth, to name just a few. It was my conversation with Mindi Abair that sparked my idea to compile a collection of my interviews with women who play jazz in all of its forms. The working title of the book is Women in Jazz.
Some great musicians, including Mindi Abair, Jane Ira Bloom, Tia Fuller, and Pamela York have already agreed to be interviewed for the book. I plan to conduct at least 15 additional interviews for the book.
Does such a book currently exist? There are plenty of books about jazz featuring men, and it is a genre that, in spite of the groundbreaking advancements several notable women, is dominated by a male worldview. So what about the women composing for and directing big bands? Or shred with the best of them in the world of jazz-fusion? story:
Big Book of Bama: Quotes of the Alabama Crimson Tide

Thanks to everyone who purchased books and helped me spread the word about the Memorable Words of Alabama project.  I hope you will now be excited about Big Book of Bama!

What started out as a project of learning self-publishing has become a much larger vision. 

A vision I'm now setting into motion.

Big Book of Bama is planned as an encyclopedic series of fan-inspired content. This first edition will focus on quotes of and about all Alabama Crimson Tide Sports, unlike the first book which only contains football quotes.

 

I Need Your Help

I am seeking to have the book professionally designed.  And, of course, with that comes several upfront expenses.  Your contributions will help offset initial costs, such as: 

  • A professional cover, hopefully desgined by one of the best in Tide Nation!
  • Professionally designed contents, highlighting certain quotes with stories/dedications/commentary.
  • Other upfront publishing costs, including promotional copies and initial marketing.

My Thanks To You

I'm so very appreciative to anyone that contributes!!  For each level of donation, I've tried to include exciting incentives like:

  • Your name in the book!
  • Fan-submitted quotes, photos, and stories!
  • Complimentary or discounted copies of the paperback!
  • FREE ebook!

Another Way You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help.  Please help spread the word by telling others about this campaign, especially via social media!

Thanks and RTR!!!

 

** Please note that contributions via PayPal are preferred, while all are extremely appreciated!

** To learn more about submitting content, include your email address or write me at singingrivermedia@gmail.com

** A portion of any proceeds that exceed my goal will be donated to Bama-related charities.

** PDF versions of the ebook and complimentary paperbacks will only be available upon completion of the project.

story:
*Goal of $3,000 is just the beginning; we need more. ALL donations are Tax-Deductible!*

Starbound Youth Ministries is the youth ministry of Faith Church of the Valley, an Evangelical Free Church located in Chandler, AZ. We are disciples of Christ who are on mission to make more disciples of Christ and to share the love and peace of Christ to the needy, broken, and lost. 

Americans often tend to think of poverty as distant and global instead of local and national. Let's be honest: the majority of us are privileged and are able to sustain some form of a comfortable lifestyle. But what's unfortunate is that our local and national poverty issue tends to dismissed, overlooked, even ignored. It is sad when students and adults are able to live without ever coming in contact with the struggles and needs of others.

This is why Starbound Youth Ministries is heading to the heart of Los Angeles. In Los Angeles alone, 90,000 people experience homelessness (with only 18,000 shelter beds in the city) each night with more than 10,000 people living on what is commonly referred to as, "Skid Row." Skid Row is an area in Los Angeles that makes up 5 square miles that is essentially a dwelling place of homeless in the city. 

Skid Row is often looked at as a place of hopelessness and depravity, unreachable and unchangeable. But isn't this description true of what Scripture says of each one of us? We were all hopeless, depraved, unreachable, and unchangeable until the Word became flesh and made His dwelling among us. If Jesus walked the earth in flesh and blood today, Skid Row would be His dwelling place ministering to the "least of these."

In the book of Acts, we see what the early Christian church looked like: "All who believed were together and had all things in common; they would sell their possessions and goods and distribute the proceeds to all, as any had need" (Acts 2:44-45).

Partner with us and help us get to Los Angeles where we can embrace the hurting, feed the hungry, clothe the naked, and be the hands and feet of Jesus loving on those who need to experience the love of Christ.

Would you consider donating to our cause? Maybe this means sacrificing your latte from Starbucks, skipping In n Out burger, or even digging deep and making your monthly tithe to this mission. We will take anything and everything, including your prayers!

*NOTE: ALL donations are tax-deductible. Upon donation, you should receive a receipt with tax information.

The Impact Abroad and at Home

The hope and prayer for this trip is that our efforts and work in Los Angeles changes lives. We pray that God would move hearts and that the Spirit would work through us in Los Angeles. Similarly, we pray that we learn innovative and creative ways to minister locally in Phoenix, AZ. 

It is my (Ryan) prayer that this trip will change the lives of Starbound students and ignite a passion in them for the lost, needy, and hurting. I want Starbound to be known more for our love, heart, and service to the "least of these" than what happens inside our walled youth room. 

Each campaign is 60 days and we will be doing two. Your funds will help cover program cost and transportation for each student. Please prayerfully consider making a tax-deductible donation to this cause.

In Christ,
Ryan Collins

story:
Short Summary

My name is Milton Milton Bradley, and I am a Licensed Fool who needs your help. I have plied my trade at both the Castle at Muskogee Oklahoma Renaissance Festival, the Whitehart Renaissance Festival and most recently at the Kansas City Renaissance Festival, where I was the featured player for the Bawdy Beer Show's "Pub Poetry" segment.

Why do I need you help? Well, it's simple -- I am putting together a compilation of my works, and that is not a cheap endeavor. However, if I do raise the requisite amount of funding, everyone who contributes at least $15 will get a copy of the finished CD and some other goodies, which I'll talk about below.

You won't just be helping some other struggling artist make just another of their many unheard albums -- in fact, you will be helping me in publishing my first album of bawdy poetry, dirty jokes and filthy sketches. If that last sentence made you uneasy, read the next paragraph. This CD will be my magnum opus -- you will finally be able to take me home with you AND get to me spew forth and shut up just by pressing a simple button. More personally, however, this will be a launching point for my routine, which is a type of vaudevillian entertainment that has been slowly dying out. If you want to help me in my personal struggle to keep this art-form alive, please consider contributing.

Now, if you're still reading this, you saw the part about how this is "dirty" poetry and jokes and whatnot.  Don't worry, I am an artist.  Even though it is R-rated filth, it is very carefully-worded and eloquent R-rated filth.  It's the kind of filth that you think: "Wow.  That's some classy filth."

What We Need & What You Get

I need $600. Simple as that. If everyone donates enough as if to purchase a CD ($15), then we only need 40 contributors. There are more "rewards" available, but we'll get to that later. The $600 will go to fees and processing of contributions and the production costs of the CD.  The majority of that will go toward CD printing/duplication, as that is the expensive part of it.

Now, as for the perks:

Contribute $1 and you'll have my thanks.  

Every contribution will get a mention on my website, thanking you for your patronage.

Contribute $5 and you'll get a custom-written limerick. You can tell me what you want the topic to be, or you can trust me as an artist to write something exceptionally vile just for you.  It will be delivered digitally.

Contribute $10 and you'll get a custom-written poem with your choice of subject matter, or a custom-written limerick with your choice of subject matter.  The poem will be delivered digitally, but the limerick can be written on parchment, hand-scribed in calligraphic font, and mailed to you anywhere in the US.

Contribute $15 and you'll get a CD. You'll also get a short-form poem, up to a page in length, waxing on a theme of your choosing, hand-scribed by my assistant in calligraphy on parchment paper. You'll also get thanked on my website. The poem and CD will be mailed together.

Contribute $25 and you'll get the CD, get a long-form poem (over a page in length), hand-scribed in calligraphy on parchment, special thanks on my website, and a mention on my CD insert.

Contribute $35 and you'll get the CD, and instead of a normal poem, you'll get an finely crafted insult in rhyming meter.  I will send it digitally, both to you, and (at your discretion) to your "target". This is for entertainment; don't be a ponce about it. Along with the insult, you'll get mentioned in the CD (or, optionally, your "victim" will) and you and your victim will be thanked, personally, on my website.

Contribute $50 and you'll get one of everything from the categories of $35 and below: CD, Poetic Insult (in place of long-form poem), Short-form poem (custom theme), Limerick (custom theme), Thanks on the CD, Thanks on my website.

Contribute $60 and you'll get a CD, and a drinking song themed however you choose, to which I will write the melody, harmony, accompaniment and lyrics.  I will record the audio, set it to pictures of myself, and upload it to YouTube.  I will make a personalized thank you for the info section of the video, a personalized thank you on my website with the video link, and put you in the "Special Thanks" section of the CD insert.  I'd throw in punch and pie, but I'm not going to mail that to you.

If you are a musician - you will also get the rights to perform this song whenever you want, provided you say: "The following song was written by Milton Milton Bradley".  If you want the music, I can send you the chord sheet separately.  

Contribute $75 and you'll get a CD, plus you will get to choose the theme of a poem, which I will write, then record video of my recitation complete with a verbal thank you, citing your support by name, you will be listed in the special thanks in the info section of the video, you will get a personalized thank you on my website with a link to the video, and you will be listed in the "Special Thanks" 

OR

"THE GAUNTLET" -- First, you'll get a CD.  Second, you'll get to throw down the gauntlet; I will write a full-length poem, and have it artistically assembled for you somehow (length-permitting, it will be decoupaged onto a frame).  But, beyond just picking the theme, you can give me a specific challenge, such as: "Must contain 's' alliterations" or "must be in dactylic nonameter".  You reserve the option of keeping the poem to yourself, or -- at your discretion -- I will take a picture and upload it to my website; either way, you'll get a personalized thank you on my website, and you'll be listed in the "Special Thanks" section of my CD insert.

Contribute $80 and you'll get the CD, plus a Music Video. Give me a theme, I'll write a song, shoot a music video of it, which will include a verbal acknowledgement of your contribution, I'll upload it to YouTube, thank you in the info section, make a personalized thank you on my website with a link to the video, and list you in my CD insert in the "Special Thanks" section.  

Contribute $100 and you'll be actively involved in the writing process of a poem I create - you can give me a theme, any challenges, and any content you want added into it.  I will send you drafts and edits, and you get to approve them.  This poem will be recorded and put onto the CD with a verbal acknowledgement of your contributions in my introductory monologue.  You will be credited on the CD, and thanked on all of my social media sites and my website.

For legal purposes, I will retain all performance and reproduction rights to any artistic works we co-author as a result of this fundraising campaign.

Contribute $600 and you'll get the "Oh Holy Hell" Grab Bag. You get, essentially, one of everything.  We'll talk.  Like, I will call you up, and we'll talk on the phone.  You tell me what you want and don't want, and I'll do my best to make it happen.  

Purchasing this option opens up stretch goal funding, so, you may get more if the campaign goes well, such as T-shirts, prints, and the like.

If I don't earn $600, I will take the money I do earn and put all of it toward the CD printing/duplication process, including whatever of my own funds I must, and the CD will be made, I'll just be a little poorer for a while.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, don't worry, I completely understand.  Here's another way you can help:

Go to my Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/miltonmilton.bradley

Read the poems I have written there.  Post something on my wall if you like them.  Then, go to your wall and share this campaign.

Go to my YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSv47jZNZu399RUJYo5RcnA

Listen to the poems I have uploaded.  Comment on them if you like them.  Then, go tell your friends about me somehow (and try to point them to this page).  

Remember IndieGoGo has some "Sharing" tools, so you can share this page very easily.

Alright, thanks for reading -- and if you help me out, a double-thank-you.  Cheers!

story:
Hello, my name is Jason. I've been trying to get these books written for over a year now, but working 7 days a week on the road makes it quite difficult. 

My main focus for this is funding drive is to be able to devote my full time to writing the first book. I will also have to edit, then self publish in order to fulfill my perks.
