·  Territorial Aggression



 

· 
By Jason Brewster



Chapter one



 



 Being a werewolf could be a pain, especially when your fiancé was human. Smiling to himself, Brian pressed the end button of his cell phone. He thought about calling his fiancé, Alyssa, but decided to surprise her. It wasn’t too often that his “weekly Sunday meetings” were cancelled.

His Alpha was out hunting tonight. There had been a couple mysterious disappearances in the last week or two. Prior to these incidents, the last thing the pack had dealt with was a lone vampire that intruded on their turf. His pack controlled the area around Sarasota, Florida. Since the humans couldn’t fend off the things that went bump in the night, the pack protected the population of their territory.

his “normal” life he managed a warehouse off Clark Road. It supplied local businesses with wholesale electronic components, golf cart parts, cooking equipment, and a plethora of other things. Like all of the other packmates, he worked for a company owned by Jonathon. He pulled his 69 Chevelle Malibu out of the paking lot, looking forward to the coming evening


Jonathon was the Alpha of the pack. Like wolves, the pack was controlled by the
strongest member, and each pack had one Alpha. Brian had heard that other
lycanthropes had different family structures, but that was only hearsay so far.
The only other lycanthrope he’d ever met was a werepanther, Josh.

Josh had no pack, he ran solo. It didn’t seem to bother him, plus he had the
wolves to back him up. Josh was an officer with the Sarasota police department.
He was the reason the meeting had been called off. Not affiliated with a pack,
he was a loner. He did share information with the pack and vice versa, which is
what was happening tonight. He had something to discuss with Jonathon that
couldn’t wait. Having a paranormal ally within the law enforcement system came
in handy.

Asides from Josh, Sarasota hosted half a dozen strong psychics and two witch
families. The only members of the families Brian had met were Margarete Armijo,
who had dealings with the pack on occasion, and Roslyn McLeary, who was in the
same class as him in high school. They had dated briefly, but there had been
too much drama. Mostly it was her family not approving of her dating a
werewolf.

Since Jonathon had called off the weekly meeting, Brian had decided to take
Alyssa out to dinner. A bartender at Chili’s during the night, she attended the
Ringling School of Art during the day. They barely had any time together, so it
was a rare treat when they got to go out. Sometimes it just seemed as though
they cohabitated in the same room. He’d fall asleep alone, and she’d wake up
alone.

Maybe this would help prevent them from drifting apart, he thought
optimistically. Of course, if they did drift apart it would solve the problem
of keeping part of his life from the woman he loved, his mind countered.
Pushing the thought from his mind, he tried to remain positive. He loved
Alyssa, just as he loved being a garou (werewolf). If he had to keep the two
separate, it was a small price to pay.

Brian was a pure bred, as were all of his packmates. The difference between
other lycanthropes and a pure bred were simple. A pure bred was born that way
and changed during the late stages of puberty, while an infected lycan changed
after surviving an attack. Since lycanthropy, like vampirism, was kept out of
mainstream science, the exact method of transmission was unknown. Although it
was known that only an attack would spread the disease, it wasn’t transmitted
sexually or by blood.

Asides from having to keep such a large part of his life a secret, he was
content. It was an extremely delicate balance, but he believed he had the act
down fairly well.

Calling a Brazilian steak house, the Rodizio Grill, he reserved a table under
his full name, Brian Craft. Finished with that he turned up the stereo. His
thoughts elsewhere, his eyes barely registered the sun soaked scenery as it
flew by,

While garou had more longevity than humans, they were by no means immortal,
like vampires. Being twenty-five Brian was just a pup. Thanks to lycan’s slower
aging, he barely looked twenty. Most people who met him and his fiancé thought
she was the older of the two, and she was only twenty-two.

They had been dating for five years, living together the past three. After his
father had died when he was eighteen, she had been the only one who could calm
his ensuing rage at the world. For two years he’d blown off her obvious
concern, trying to drown his pain in drugs, alcohol, and violence. Being a
garou, drugs and alcohol didn’t work as well as it did for humans. Plus, when
you can heal broken bones in the space of ten minutes, it was hard to have
enough pain inflicted upon him to mask the emotional distress he had felt.

Two years of her unwavering attention while he watched her mature into a
beautiful young woman had done its damage. Unwittingly, he had become
enraptured with her, despite his attempts to ignore her. Once their
relationship had started, it had matured slowly.

The more he thought about it, the fact that it wasn’t a whirlwind of a
relationship is probably what had helped hold it together. While most of their
friends had loved and lost, their emotional bond had only grown stronger. He’d
have thought that spending too much time together would be their downfall, but
now the reverse worried him.

Pulling the green muscle car off of Clark road, he made a right onto Colonial
Street. Passing the single story houses with their bright green, well kept
yards, he pressed the garage door opener attached to the sun visor. The door
opened before he came to the stop sign where Colonial met Williamsburg Street
and ended. Driving the Chevelle through the slight jog to the left and up the
driveway, he parked next to Alyssa’s white 2008 Mustang GT.

Pushing the garage door opener, he killed the large engine. He got out of the
car, walking past the white washer and dryer and up the three steps to the door
leading inside. Standing momentarily, he listened at the door. He could hear
music playing and the sound, barely audible even to his extraordinary hearing,
of pencil tip moving against paper.

Opening the door, he walked into the entryway and removed his shoes. The
entryway was covered in white wallpaper with floral designs on it, a large
mirror between the front and garage doors, the floor was polished hardwood. It
wrapped around to the right to meet the front door, a small white wooden doored
closet to the left. The wall between the living room and entryway was only
seven feet high and didn’t extend to the ceiling. An open four foot rectangle
cut into the wall connected the two instead of a door.

The living room was painted white, the carpet beige. Three of Alyssa’s
paintings adorned the walls. There was also a forty-eight inch flat screen TV
on a stand that held all the audio\visual electronics in it, a large beige pit
group, and a wooden coffee table with four glass inserts in the top. Two thirds
of the length of the room back, the carpet ended and the off white tile of the
dining room began.

Centered to the breakfast bar, cut into the wall separating the kitchen and
dining room, sat a brass and glass table with four black and brass chairs.
Alyssa sat in the chair that faced the kitchen, with her back to the front
door, and prismacolored drawings spread over the table around her. Her long
blonde hair was braided in pigtails and swung as she turned to look over her
shoulder. She was dressed in an old GWAR shirt of Brian’s and a pair of ripped
blue jeans, her feet bare.

He could smell a faint tinge of fear on the air, mingling with her scent. As
she saw him approach, a flitter of relief played across her face. “Hi babe, did
you forget something?” She asked.

“No, something came up, so the meeting is cancelled.” He bent down and kissed her
forehead. Standing erect, he looked into her vivid blue eyes. “So I made
reservations at Rodizio’s for us.”

“Have you done something I should know about?” She teased him, smiling good
naturedly.

The smile was infectious, and his face split into one. “No, little girl. I just
thought we should take advantage of tonight.”

“Sounds great. How long until we’re supposed to be there?”

“Well, just in case you were doing something, I made the reservations for eight
forty-five.”

“Silly boy, you know I don’t have anything going on. It’s the beginning of my
weekend.”

“Hey, I never know. With my luck you’d have been out with friends till eight if
I’d made the reservations for seven thirty. Plus, I wanted to get a workout in
while I have a chance.”

Standing up, she gave him a hug. “Thanks, babe.”

“For what?” he asked with an arched brow.

“For being a loving, thoughtful boyfriend, and a little dense.” She winked at
him surreptitiously.

He gave her a quick kiss. “Thanks, I think.” Leaving her to her artwork, he
walked back through the living room and down the hallway to the right. The
hallway led to the weight room, guestroom and guest bathroom.

Entering the second door on the right, he pulled off his polo shirt and khakis
and put on the Miami Heat basketball shorts lying on the floor. Tossing the
clothes in a pile by the door, he found the I-pod he kept in the room and
inserted the ear pieces, putting the little machine on random. Lying down on
the cool vinyl bench, he brought the barbell up off the stand. As Ministry began
blaring in his ears he started to bench press the two hundred pounds he was
holding.

Thankfully the altered healing factor of lycanthropes made it really difficult
to blow up like Conan-era Arnold. It allowed them to gain tremendous strength
without getting a huge physique. Although it took a conscious effort to have a
soft touch, he thought as he pushed up another rep.

After about fifteen reps he began to sweat a little, showing no other signs of
exertion. His breathing was timed to the reps, but he wasn’t huffing or
panting. Even his face appeared relaxed as his mind continued to run amok.

The only things that a lycanthrope’s healing factor couldn’t deal with quickly
were wounds caused by other lycan’s claws or teeth while in wereform, silver,
and vampiric bites or claw wounds. It caused one to have a lower regard for
personal safety. Although, normal bullets and blades could still kill a lycan
if the head could be severed completely off, the brain destroyed or the lycan
bled to death.

Of course, there was another side to all of it. You couldn’t just take a bullet
to the chest in front of witnesses and walk away nonchalantly. There was a
covenant that most lycans and vampires adhered to. Basically it said that all
the supernatural dirt had to be done out of the public eye. Also, they could
never reveal themselves to humans, not even family.

Brian almost laughed at the thought. Yeah, hey guys, sorry to inform you, but
your bloodline is tainted with a disease that only shows up once every couple
thousand births. Oh, and I have it. Yeah, it makes me change into the wolfman.
No seriously.

The downside was that he would never be able to tell Alyssa about it. He’d have
to cringe in mock fear if some punk ever pulled a gun on them. When what he’d
really want to do is stomp a hole in him. Then again it was all conjecture.
Point was, he would always be lying. He couldn’t stop being a garou, and he
wouldn’t give up Alyssa. No matter how much nay saying they had done.

He could still remember when the little fourteen year old punk girl hit the
scene in Sarasota. Little did he realize, he’d later think of the event as
divine intervention. She had just moved with her parents from Kingman, Az. For
reasons he still couldn’t fathom, she had been drawn to him like a moth to flame.

Not the typical teenager in anyway, he had fended off the young girls
inexplicable attraction to him, while his friends his age had dated girls as
young as her or younger. As much as he’d blown her off, she had blown his
friends off twice as much, he thought with a rueful smile. Guess that proves
she wasn’t like other girls her age. Most of them were so starved for affection
that they weren’t without a boyfriend for more than a couple days at a time.

Then his father had succumbed to cancer, and Brian got a glimpse of what his
future was to be like. Living longer than his human counterparts, he would be
forced to watch everyone he knew or loved die. Lo and behold, the young Brian
had rebelled. It was funny, no amount of normal teenage angst could cause said
rebellion. Life had been too new and full of surprises. He’d only found out he
was a garou two and a half years before it happened.

He’d quickly gained the reputation of being a quick tempered, heavy drinking,
drug gobbling badass. He rarely lost a fight, even when he was jumped. As far
as he was concerned the covenant could be damned. The only beatings he took
were administered by his packmates.

Jonathon had especially taken offense to his attitude. Of his two pack
enforcers, Matt had been the more sympathetic. His “lessons” had been geared
more towards future conflict, while Jack’s (the other pack enforcer) and
Jonathon’s had been straight punishment, meant as an attitude adjustments.

Yet none of that could dent the huge amount of rage he’d felt, nothing but one
little seventeen year old girl. He could still remember that fateful evening
with crystal clarity.

It had been a weekend night towards the end of summer. Brian had been aimless
since graduation two years prior. His employment by Jonathon was wearing thin.
More often than not, he found himself getting a lesson from one or more of his
packmates instead of actually working at the warehouse. So, in typical weekend
fashion, he found himself at the Blue Parrot bar catching a punk show and
blowing off steam.

The Parrot was a great venue that had closed down later. It’d had all ages
shows and served alcohol. People usually had to go north to Tampa-St. Pete to
find that. The only drawback of the bar was its tiny layout. It was only twenty
feet across and eighty feet back, not including the backstage area. Coming from
the front door, about forty feet of space was taken up by tables and the bar
that ran along the wall to the right. Behind the bar, stairs ran up to the
second floor that over looked the bar and was filled with couches and little
tables.

The stage only took up twelve feet and was elevated just a few inches above the
floor. The rest of the space was taken up by the pit area which had two support
beams in it. The two foot across square concrete posts had been known to be
hazardous to people’s health, especially when the pit was rambunctious, as it
was on this evening. Brian manhandled his way through it, bouncing off people
and slamming others at random.

He had discovered that lsd was one of the only drugs his souped up metabolism
couldn’t pump out quickly, so he’d eaten a few hits on top of a lot of
Jagermeister and a bit of nose candy. The aggressive tempo of the music was
bringing him closer and closer to a frenzy.

Towards the end of the song, he began to batter the other people in the pit. A
well placed punch here, an elbow there, shoulder check that guy into a support
post, and rebound with an elbow to some guys face. He flew around, concentrated
mayhem on a destruction mission.

Walking out of the pit to the bar when the song ended, he ordered a Bud Lite
draft. Upending the glass, he slammed the beer before leaving the empty mug on
the bar and sauntering outside. In contrast to the stifling club filled with
hot, sweaty bodies, the night air was crisp and refreshing, with a slight
chill.

Greedily, he sucked in large gulps of fresh air. There was a motley collection
of punks, skins, and scenesters hanging around the entrance and the bench
located on the side walk by the road. He nodded to a group of his old friends
that included Alyssa.

Her hair was dyed orange with black tips that night. She had let it down for
once. Wearing white knee high stockings with short oxblood Doc Martin boots, a
plaid skirt and a black Against All Authority tank top, she was quite a
fetching sight. She stared him in the eyes, unnerving him slightly.

It wasn’t that she wasn’t attractive, or that he had a problem approaching
women, he just didn’t see her in that light yet. All he was after was the
conquests. Although he wouldn’t admit it, he cared for her too much to use and
discard her. Plus, she was immature compared to the women he went after. His
new found confidence had given him access to older women, including the
bartender that was serving him even though he was underage.

Watching the faces of the young kids around him distort and melt, he didn’t pay
attention as four guys came out of the bar behind him. Their voices floating up
from the doorway also didn’t register with his acid soaked mind.

“Is that the asshole from the pit?”

“Yeah, that’s him.”

“Hey! You!” The yelling caused him to turn around, a fist caused him to spin
back. Having been sucker punched brought him out of his stupor and straight
into attack mode. He was like a pitbull that had been fed black powder.

Landing a solid hook to his attacker, he knocked out the first of the four.
Before the guy could hit the sidewalk, Brian followed up with a straight right
into the guy’s nose, adding insult to injury.

Out of his peripheral vision, he saw one of his old friends, Cory, stalking the
other three. His hand was about to go into the pocket of his leather jacket,
where Brian knew he carried brass knuckles. The thought that someone was going
to try to save him made him smile.

“Cory, don’t. I’ve got this,” he said, still smiling maniacally.

His friend stared at him incredulously, shrugging. The mixture of the lunatic
grin, the confidence he exuded, and the fact he’d just called off the only help
he had caused the remaining three attackers to hesitate.

Jumping on the opportunity, Brian slammed an elbow into the jaw of the attacker
closest to him. He went down in a heap, and Brian heard the sound of Mario
collecting a gold coin in the video game Super Mario Bros. Before the next guy
could lift his arms, his face had already been stuffed with three quick,
powerful punches. With every hit, the coin sound played in Brian’s head.

The last guy standing had gathered the presence of mind to run. The smell of
his fear excited Brian even more. Before the poor guy could run a dozen steps,
he was spun around and headbutted viciously, twice.

Brian lost it. He began screaming as he held up his slack body with one hand.
The other hand punctuated each word with a brutal punch. “Try to jump me, huh?
Who do you think you are? Four on one, huh?” He started slamming his fist into
the jelly that had been the guy’s face with every syllable. “Bad fucking
mistake, asshole.”

Lost in the moment, he didn’t hear the diminutive voice behind him. “Brian,
please.” But he did feel the hand on his shoulder when she placed it there to
stop him.

He dropped his victim and spun around, snatching Alyssa up by her neck with one
hand. His right hand pistoned back to start battering his newest target. His
face was twisted in a mask of hatred and rage.

His mind recoiled at the fear, compassion, worry, and love etched on the face
of the beautiful girl he was about to pound into a bloody mess of broken bone
and flesh. Everything stopped, and the walls of hate and rage he had built
around the grief for his father came crashing down.

Letting go of her, a single tear ran from his eye. His acid soaked brain began
to make connections. He had never truly grieved for his father, just covered it
up. He actually loved the little girl in front of him, and she really, truly
loved him.

Turning off his memories, he set the bar back on its stand with a mighty heave.
Although the memories were a great motivator when working out, that part always
drained him. He laid there, his sweat turning cool, as he felt the torn muscles
repairing themselves.

After a couple of minutes, he got up and started doing military benches,
reminiscing again. He thought of how happy the pack had been when he finally
came around. Until they found out the reason, that was.

Smiling, he wondered why, when everything they had said to him to calm him had
bounced right off, they suddenly thought their advice would stick. None of them
understood why he choose would the hassle of a permanent human mate. Jonathon
was convinced he would betray the covenant at first. Matt continually extolled
the virtues of a garou mate. Which he would, being mated to Sarah, who was
another packmate. At the time she was the only other female in the pack.

Over the years they had grown to know and accept her. Jonathon was the sole
holdout, but it didn’t seem to matter that the owner of a business was aloof
around his manager’s fiancé. Matt and Sarah had become their best friends, as
far as couples were concerned. There were still the occasional prophetic
doomsday comments, but Brian thought they had decided to let him live his own
life.

Lifting the small forty pound dumbbell over his head for the umpteenth time, he
ruminated that it was probably a lot easier not trying to tell him how to live
now that he’d quit being such a jerk. Plus there weren’t many possible
repercussions for the pack. He was only messing up his own life.

Her family had actually put up more of a fight than his pack had. To them,
Brian had no future, or at least not one good enough for Alyssa. It hadn’t
helped that his reputation preceded him to the point where both her younger
sisters and older brother knew of him, none of it good. He’d even had to
swallow his pride and not retaliate when her brother had sucker punched him.

In his opinion, they still didn’t believe he was good enough for her, but at
least they had quit trying to pull them apart. It probably had a lot to do with
her blowing them off after the incident with her brother. Brian still felt
pride at the amount of self restraint he had shown that day. He knew Alyssa was
very proud that he had kept his cool. His relationship with her brother, Josh,
was barely amicable to this day.

Where once he had felt nothing could come between them, now budding seeds of
doubt began to bloom. While his rational mind knew it was only the amount of
time spent apart, he couldn’t quell the feeling of unease he’d begun to have.
As soon as he had let any doubt in, it had begun to eat at him.

Well hopefully tonight will help put some of that to rest, he thought. It was
definitely good luck that had brought him this opportunity. He knew he should
just blow off the irrational thoughts, but it was more easily said than done.
He blew out a heavy sigh, pumping out three more reps before changing exercises
again.

As he started doing single curls, alternating hands, he tried to clear his
mind. Dwelling on the subject just gave it more sustenance, which was the last
thing he needed to do. Instead, he focused on the music pouring into his ears.
Timing his reps to coincide with the rhythm, he zoned out.

Finishing up, he replaced all the weights and the I-pod to their prearranged
spots. Leaving the room, he switched off the lights. He strode into the living
room on his way to the master bedroom. Alyssa was hunched over one of her
drawings, lost to the world, her colored pencil a blur. Other drawings still
lay on the glass dining room table, an arch of art around her.

The picture she was working on reminded Brian of a bad acid trip. It was one of
her few darker pieces, an expedition into her subconscious. It was kind of
post-apocalyptic; a burnt, melted cityscape with half decomposed bodies lying
in the street that made up the foreground.

Even with that subject, the picture had beauty. The sky was a pink and purple
sunset. The colors reflected off the towering lumps of melted glass that had
once been skyscrapers. Plus, he noted, the detail was amazing.

The door to the master bedroom was off the dining room. Moving stealthily, he
retreated through it and closed the door softly. He didn’t want to ruin her
concentration. Stripping off the shorts he went straight for the master
bathroom. Padding over cool tile, he moved quietly to the shower and turned it
on. Stepping into the small room of a shower, he let the water sluice the sweat
and dirt from his body. He luxuriated in the hot spray.



Chapter two

The dinner had gone well, and Brian was looking forward to taking his fiancé
home. He could tell from her scent and body language that she was anticipating
what would follow when they got there.

Walking out of the Rodizio Grill, Brian caught the faint scent of an unfamiliar
garou in werewolf form. He didn’t even recognize the garou’s bloodline, but
could tell it wasn’t an Alpha or a pure bred. Inhaling deeply through his nose,
he could tell the garou was actually a fair distance away. He realized that if
the balmy wind hadn’t been from the southwest, he would never have caught the
scent.

“You alright, babe?” Alyssa asked looking at him with a puzzled expression on
her beautiful face, her head cocked slightly to one side. Brian looked down
then swept his gaze up from her black stiletto heels, over the creamy expanse
of leg, over the small black cocktail dress that clung to her body. He tried to
imprint the picture to his memory, knowing he couldn’t stay with her now.

“Sorry, baby. I’ve got a lot of shit on my mind. I think it’d be better if I
walk back to the house. Just to clear my head.” Although lying to her was
almost painful, he could see no way around it. This part of his life would
always be a secret.

“What’s wrong?” She stepped closer to him, the scent of her perfume mingled
with the unique musk that was all her own and filled his nostrils.

“It’s just from shit from work. I’m sorry, baby, but I won’t be worth a damn
till I figure this out. I’m still coming home, I promise. I just need this.” He
didn’t know what else to say, and he was afraid if he waited much longer, he’d
lose the scent.

Leveling her head and frowning slightly, she answered, “If you say so. Try not
to be too long, ok?”

Nodding, Brian watched her walk to her Mustang, his eyes fixated on her ass
through the thin material of her dress. For a split second he forgot about the
other garou, but he caught the faint scent once again on the humid night air.
He cursed the sacrifices he was sometimes forced to make, turning and walking
away as Alyssa got into her car.

Once out of her sight, he moved quickly. Leaving the Gulf Gate business
district, he started passing one story suburban homes. Reaching into the gray
slacks he realized he had left his cell phone at home. While it was a fortunate
mistake if Alyssa tried to call him, it meant he couldn’t inform his packmates.
He was going in solo. Nearing the garou’s location, he began searching for a
deserted house or yard. His hazel eyes lit upon a for sale sign a couple houses
down.

Walking down the street, he watched the houses and yards for any sign of being
watched. He saw no one, and the little white house appeared vacant. Walking
towards up the concrete drive, he sniffed the air. He was still downwind of the
garou and there were no canines in the vicinity.

Some dogs acted weird around garou in human form, although most were
frightened. When a dog was around a garou changing shape, they went nuts. It
was the kind of attention he had to avoid.

He hurdled the three foot chain link fence without breaking stride, darting
into the shadows. Once in the shelter of the dark backyard, he stripped
quickly. Folding the grey slacks, black button up shirt and boxers, he put them
on top of his shoes on the small wooden deck.

Taking a deep breath, he forced himself to change. His back arched as pain
ripped through him. His five foot eleven inch frame began to grow, light brown
fur rippling over his body. There was an audible crack as his facial bones
shifted to allow a snout to flow forward. Two more followed as his knees popped
backwards. Moonlight glinted off of his teeth as they grew past his lips, a
twisted grimace on his flowing face. Thirty seconds after the change had
started, it was over. He breathed a sigh of relief as the pain receded.

He bounded over the fence and into drainage ditch, running towards where the
scent originated from. He let himself go, tearing through palmetto bushes,
reveling in the physical sensations of his muscles uncoiling and the wind in
his fur.

Seemingly no sooner than he had started to run, he was behind the house the
garou was in, looking through the back sliding glass door. Seeing no movement
inside the living room, he used his advanced senses to try and ascertain what
was going on. His pulse quickened as he scented fear and blood. A low moan of
anguish was barely audible.

He launched himself though the glass door, avoiding the white leather furniture
and little wooden coffee table. Landing on the thick white shag carpeting, he
rolled to his feet and ran into the short hallway to the right. The second door
on the left was slightly ajar, the assaulting stench of fear, anguish, and
human blood wafting from it.

Bounding towards the door, he stopped two feet from it and pushed it open
gently, beware of a trap. Rage boiled inside of him at the sight that greeted
his eyes.

It was apparent that the huge black garou hadn’t heard the glass breaking; he
was so intent on ravaging his victim. Splatters of blood randomly sprayed the
white walls and ceiling crimson. The large beast had its claws and teeth sunk
into the body on the brass frame bed. Sheets black with blood dripped onto the
carpet staining it red.

Brian launched himself at the beast’s bared back, taking advantage of his
opponent’s inattention. He clamped his teeth into its right shoulder, sinking
his claws into the left shoulder and right bicep. The huge size of the garou
was even more apparent once he was latched on. Brian’s rear claws were two feet
off the ground, tearing at the back of his adversary’s legs as he scrambled to
find some grip. He flexed his jaw muscles, trying to shatter the huge beast’s
collarbone or separate it’s rotator cuff.

His opponent reacted, seizing him by the neck and flinging him across the room.
The action caused Brian to rip chunks from the garou’s shoulders. Brian flew
into the stained cedar dresser opposite the door to the hall. The force of the
impact drove the dresser into the drywall breaking it and cracking the studs
behind it.

Jumping up, Brain faced the huge black beast. Blood ran from both shoulders
matting the fur. The right shoulder and arm were worse wounds than the left
shoulder, but none of the wounds seemed like enough to even slow his opponent
down. Brian spit the mouthful of flesh and fur on the carpet. Doing so was an
insult by garou customs. Basically, he just said he had no respect and nothing
to fear from him. As his adversary came around the bed between them, Brian
improved his stance, settling his weight on the balls of his feet.

In a blur of superhuman speed the massive black beast rushed him, swinging
wildly. Brian ducked under a right and sidestepped. He raked his claws across
its abdomen, opening four wounds. The garou whirled, cracking him in the side
of the head with a spinning back fist.

His adversary tried to press the advantage, throwing a powerful right haymaker.
Ducking underneath, he stepped closer to the garou, smothering its power. He
slammed a left elbow into its solar plexus, following up with a right elbow to
the snout. Brian was grabbed and tossed into the wall to the right. The garou
shook his head to clear it before lunging at Brian again.

He hit the wall, bounced to the floor, rolled and came up crouched, white
drywall dust in his fur. Using his legs to explode forward, he met the garou in
the air. Its momentum was too much to overcome, and they ended up on the floor.
Brian was on his back below the beast, barely holding its snapping maw from his
face and neck.

Wrapping its hands around Brian’s neck, the garou started squeezing, choking
him. He moved his hold off the beast so that he was gripping the upper and
lower jaws and began to wrench them apart. His adversary grunted and released
the strangle hold, allowing Brian to twist around to his hands and knees. The
garou blasted the back of his head with a flurry of punches, only stopping to
wrap him in a bear hug as Brian stood up.

Pretending to struggle, he jockeyed his left foot behind the beast. Bending his
right knee, he swept his opponents foot forward as he snapped his right leg
straight, pushing the garou over on his back and landing on top of it. The
impact sent the air rushing from the beast’s lungs, causing it to loosen the
bear hug. Brian used the slight break to twist around and lunge up, freeing his
arms. Using short quick swipes, he started raking his claws down its face.

The beast released the hold of Brian’s abdomen to grab his wrists. Brian
lowered his snout and snapped a little chunk of flesh from its chest. Once
again he spit the mouthful out, this time in its face. Wrestling with the garou
he finally pinned its left arm under his right knee.

He began to rain punishment down on his opponent, alternating punches, elbow
strikes, facial slashes, and when no other opening presented itself, he slashed
its right shoulder and arm. The massive garou bucked until it freed its arm,
spinning to its hands and knees.

Brian was ready for this and ran his claws down its back before putting some
distance between them. He watched the beast warily as it whirled around to face
him once again. Blood ran from more than a dozen wounds.

He knew the only reason he wasn’t dead yet was because his adversary was
relying on brute force instead of skill and experience. He also noted that the
garou fought as a human would, not like a werewolf should. He thanked his lucky
stars the beast wasn’t properly trained.

Deciding to play with it a little, he assumed a boxer’s stance and asked, “Hey
Fido, does your Alpha know you’re attacking humans.” His voice was distorted
from speaking through a snout, and it was lower due to changed vocal chords.

The huge garou gave a throaty laugh. “Stupid pup, this is a recruitment.” It
swung a wild right haymaker.

Ducking under the blow, he slammed a right to the body followed by a left hook
to its face. The garou stumbled back two steps and threw a left hook. Circling
to his right, Brian caught the punch and blasted a hard jab into its snout.

The beast howled in rage, grabbing Brian and tossing him into the wall above
the dresser once again. Drywall and studs broke as he went into and through the
wall, landing on the beige tile of the master bathroom.

Rising to his feet, he looked back at the master bedroom through the hole in
the wall. The garou tossed the dresser to the side and kicked the lower part of
the wall in. Gripping the hole in the wall on either side, it ripped the wall
down, enlarging the hole.

Brian ripped the porcelain sink from the wall as the beast broke a stud, making
room for it to fit through. Water gushed from the broken pipes, drenching him
as the garou entered the bathroom. Gripping the sink in his left hand he
feinted a strike with it. His adversary went to block and Brian ripped his
right claw across its stomach. He ducked a wild right and smashed the sink
across its head opening a large gash along the side of it. The chunk of the
sink in his right hand protruded about five inches from his closed fist,
tapering into a curved point. Brian then had to eat a left hook in order to
land an overhand right of his own.

Ducking another wild right, he slammed the makeshift porcelain shank into the
garou’s exposed stomach. As Brian sank it into the beast’s stomach again it
grabbed him by his right shoulder with its left hand and slammed a vicious
right into his face. He saw a bright flash of white light before the powerful
blow knocked him into a punch drunk daze. His adversary laughed with a deep
rumbling sound.

Even a little out of it, he knew that he wouldn’t survive if he took many more
of these powerful blows. If he were to be knocked unconscious, the beast could
kill him at its leisure. Watching its right fist as the garou drew back for the
next blow, desperation took hold in Brian. Before the fist could streak towards
him again he jammed the makeshift shank into the underside of the beast’s jaw.
It yelped in surprise and Brian opened his hand, slamming his palm into the
porcelain to drive it deeper.

The garou released its grip and howled in anguish, reaching for it’s wounded
snout with both hands. Brian blasted a right hook into its face then slashed it
with his left claw. Keeping the momentum going he popped two quick jabs into
its wounded snout before catching the chunk of porcelain with a right uppercut.

Brian pressed his advantage, slowly walking the garou back, out of the
bathroom, hitting it with quick straight strikes. Once he had it backed
sufficiently into the master bedroom, he began to circle to his right.
Switching from knuckles to claws, he continued his vicious attack. The large
garou bellowed, pulling the chunk of porcelain from its snot. His chest, stomach,
and arms were a mess of bleeding slashes.

Brian ducked its attempt to imbed the chunk into his face, stepping in and
sinking his right claws into its stomach almost to the first knuckle. He did
the same with to the garou’s right calf. Sinking his teeth into its hamstrings,
he attempted to hobble the giant.

Once again Brian found himself hurtling through the hole in the wall. This time
the impact cracked drywall, cinderblock, and shattered the mirror above where
the sink had been. He landed in a puddle, water cascading onto him.

He pushed himself to his feet, spitting the newest chunk of flesh onto the wet
tiles. Peering through ten hole, he expected the huge garou to follow him into
the bathroom, Instead the bedroom was abandoned, the door to the hall still
swinging.

Brian shook himself, spraying the bathroom with the water in his fur before
bounding after his opponent. He stayed low, running on all fours to avoid any
possible ambushes. Not spotting his prey in the hall, he ran into the living
room. As he rounded the corner, he found the coffee table sailing through the
air at him.

He took the impact on his forearms, deflecting the table to the left, rising,
his arms raised to block the next attack. Once his line of sight was clear of
flying furniture, he saw the large garou disappear into the drainage ditch.

He started towards the broken sliding glass door to follow before thinking
better of it. He padded back into the bedroom, creeping up to the bed. The
bloody mess on the bed was still breathing. Walking back into the living room,
he searched until he found a Thrasher magazine with the address on it. Finding
a phone in the kitchen, he dialed a number from memory. It took two attempts of
hitting the buttons with his claws.

“Hello?’ A female answered.

“Hey Sarah, can I yell at Matt? It’s Brian.”

“Umm, yeah, just a sec,” she said, puzzlement evident in her voice.

After a couple moments Matt came on the line. “Hey bro, what’s up?”

“Sorry to bother you, but I have a problem. I need you to come to…” Brian
looked at the address and recited it.

“OK, what’s goin on?”

“I’ve got an attack survivor. I fought off the garou, and I need you to look
after this kid.”

“Fuck. Did you tell Jonathon?”

“Nope. I was hoping you could fill him in. I’m on this guy’s landline, and Jonathon
would kill me if I called his phone,” Brian explained.

“Yeah, you’ve gotta point. I’ll be there as soon as possible.”

“Thanks.” The line was already dead.

He crept warily back into the bedroom, surveying the extent of the damage to
the person in the bloody bed. The victim was severely ravaged most of the
muscle and flesh of the right leg was gone. Both of his forearms, chest, face,
and left bicep were also torn asunder. Checking the victim’s vitals, Brian
realized two things in quick succession. First, the victim was male. The second
realization was that the guy had fallen into a lycanthropic healing coma, and
the wounds were already beginning to close.

Brian didn’t know much about infected victims, but it didn’t seem normal for
someone so recently infected to be able to enter a healing sleep already. He
shook his head. Keeping his senses alert for the return of his opponent, he
began to clean up.

He wrapped the young male’s worst wounds with what little bedding wasn’t
already soaked in blood. Once the guy was situated as well as could be, he
waded through the destruction of the bathroom. Finding the water shut off
valve, he stopped the water cascading onto the tiles. Searching the small room
for garbage bags, he came up empty.

Checking on the victim, he found the kid’s pulse stronger, his breathing less
shallow and irregular. Satisfied the kid would be alright, he proceeding
through the house to the kitchen. He stopped in the living room, taking in a
deep breath of warm night air coming in through the broken sliding glass door.
There was no trace of any garou scents.

Rifling through drawers and cabinets, he came upon some hefty bags. He carried
his find back into the bedroom, remaining in were form incase the garou from
earlier came back. Since he had no weapons, it seemed like the best idea.

Gathering the bloody remains of the bedding, he bagged it. Using his claws, he
cut the blood soaked carpet. Shouldering the bed out of his way, he collected
the carpet scraps and bagged them also. Finished with that, he looked about for
the porcelain shank from earlier. After an exhaustive search of the bed and
bath rooms came up with nothing, he broadened his search to the other rooms. He
finally located the chunk in the living room, lying on the carpet by the couch.

He was about to go back into the bed room when he caught the sound of an engine
coming down the quiet suburban street. The noise grew closer, headlights
lighting the room as the vehicle swung into the drive.

Brian bounded to the window, using one claw to raise a blind. He was rewarded
with the sight of Matt’s battered grey Silverado running in the drive. The
wiry, brown skinned male in his apparent mid twenties was Brian’s packmate.
Matt ran his hand over his short cropped black hair, sniffing the air. He was
dressed as usual in climbing boots, jeans, and a black t-shirt

Brian realized he’d been holding his breath and released it. He unlocked the
front door then moved back out of view as Matt walked up. In the pack hierarchy
he was immediately above Brian, and was his closest confidant.

“Come in.” Brian said in a normal volume. Matt walked in, quickly shutting the
door. Brian continued, “Sorry to interrupt your evening.’

Matt cracked his trademark, devil may cry smile. “Don’t worry about it, got me
out of the house.”

“Please tell me you brought some firepower?”

“Of course,” Matt replied, pulling a Desert Eagle .357 from the waist band of
his jeans.

Brian’s were form rippled as the fur retracted into the body as it shrank back
to human. His naked body was completely clean. Even the scent of the other
Garou was gone. Taking the pistol from Matt, he hefted the reassuring weight,
smiling. His left hand still held the chunk of porcelain.

Matt’s smile never faltered. “So what the fuck happened?’

Shaking his head, Brian began his summary. While he related the story, he led
Matt back into the bedroom. Matt’s brown eyes quickly took in the scene,
darting over the damage to the room, the two black trash bags, and settling on
the victim’s still form. As the two moved closer to the bed, Matt’s smile
faded.

“The damage was worse. He’s fallen into a regenerative coma,” Brian observed.

“Fuck,” Matt said with a shrug of his shoulders, “it’s better than a body.
Still, Jonathon is going to be pissed.”

Brian pulled his gaze from the young male’s slowly healing wounds, looking up
into Matt’s face. “Did you talk to him?”

Matt’s smile returned. “Left that for Sarah. You want to talk about pissed.”

“Shit, so you don’t know what the plan is?”\

“I talked to her on the way over. I’m taking our friend here to Carlos’s house.
We’re all meeting up at the warehouse early in the morning. I guess Josh had
some bad news.”

“Yeah, I bet it has something to do with this. And what the fuck is early?”

“Around six. What time do you start opening?”

“Seven, so that should be fine. How do you want to do this?” Brian motioned to
the inert body they were standing next to.

“Fuck, I wish Jonathon was here.” Matt paused before starting back up. “Wrap
him in a blanket, toss him in the cab. I guess.”

“You mind doing that while I find some clothes and pack him a bag?”

“No problem.” Matt started searching for a comforter, Brian having already
bagged the bloody one.



He walked through the debris back into the
bedroom, wiping his feet on the carpet to clean them off. Matt was rolling the
body in a green comforter, while Brian scoured the closet. Finding an old gym
bag, he filled it with clothes.

Selecting a pair of ripped jeans that would fit his waist and an old flannel
shirt, he put them on. He stuffed the .357 into the waistband and rolled up the
excess of the long jeans. He then slipped on a pair of Nike’s that were too
large for him, tossing a newer pair in the bag.

Shouldering the gym bag, he snatched up the two garbage bags and strode out of
the house. Matt cradled the blanket swathed young man and followed. Brian
tossed the bags into the truck, while Matt stuck the motionless body into the
cab.

Matt closed the passenger door softly. “You need a ride?”

“No, I still have to get my clothes and change back.”

Matt chuckled, “Guess I’ll see you in the morning.”

“Thanks again.”

Watching Matt drive down the street, Brian looked for signs some concerned
citizen had witnessed the scene. It seemed as nothing was amiss, so he turned
and walked back through the still open front door.

Doing a thorough scan of the house, he made sure to leave no signs but the
damage done to the house. He found three chunks of meat, now furless, and
tossed them in a garbage bag. Since the only way back to his clothes that he
knew went through the drainage ditch, he left that way.

As he picked his way through the palmetto bushes crowding the ditch, he kept
his right hand on the butt of the Desert Eagle. Although he couldn’t smell, see
or otherwise sense any enemies, he thought it wise to err on the side of
caution.

He effortlessly jumped the chain link fence, back into the yard were he’d left
his clothes. Tossing the clothes he was wearing in a pile, he stripped in the
light of a half full moon. At least there is some time before the next full
moon, he thought. He finished dressing, his mind going over all the
difficulties the pack was in for because of this. Picking up the gun and
clothes, he tossed the clothes into the garbage bag with chunks of meat. He
tucked the pistol into the grey slacks.

Starting back towards the street, he pushed the thoughts from his mind. He kept
a constant vigil for any sign of an ambush, scenting the air. His right thumb
was hooked in his slack pocket, keeping the hand close to the pistol. He tossed
the garbage bag into a can left by the street a few houses down, walking back
to his house
