Territorial Aggression · By Jason BrewsterChapter one  Being a
werewolf could be a pain, especially when your fiancé was human. Smiling to
himself, Brian pressed the end button of his cell phone. He thought about
calling his fiancé, Alyssa, but decided to surprise her. It wasn’t too often
that his “weekly Sunday meetings” were cancelled.
His Alpha was out hunting tonight. There had been a couple mysterious
disappearances in the last week or two. Prior to these incidents, the last
thing the pack had dealt with was a lone vampire that intruded on their turf.
His pack controlled the area around Sarasota, Florida. Since the humans
couldn’t fend off the things that went bump in the night, the pack protected
the population of their territory.
his “normal” life he managed a warehouse off Clark Road. It supplied local
businesses with wholesale electronic components, golf cart parts, cooking
equipment, and a plethora of other things. Like all of the other packmates, he
worked for a company owned by Jonathon. He pulled his 69 Chevelle Malibu out of
the paking lot, looking forward to the coming evening
Jonathon was the Alpha of the pack. Like wolves, the pack was controlled by thestrongest member, and each pack had one Alpha. Brian had heard that otherlycanthropes had different family structures, but that was only hearsay so far.The only other lycanthrope he’d ever met was a werepanther, Josh.Josh had no pack, he ran solo. It didn’t seem to bother him, plus he had thewolves to back him up. Josh was an officer with the Sarasota police department.He was the reason the meeting had been called off. Not affiliated with a pack,he was a loner. He did share information with the pack and vice versa, which iswhat was happening tonight. He had something to discuss with Jonathon thatcouldn’t wait. Having a paranormal ally within the law enforcement system camein handy.Asides from Josh, Sarasota hosted half a dozen strong psychics and two witchfamilies. The only members of the families Brian had met were Margarete Armijo,who had dealings with the pack on occasion, and Roslyn McLeary, who was in thesame class as him in high school. They had dated briefly, but there had beentoo much drama. Mostly it was her family not approving of her dating awerewolf.Since Jonathon had called off the weekly meeting, Brian had decided to takeAlyssa out to dinner. A bartender at Chili’s during the night, she attended theRingling School of Art during the day. They barely had any time together, so itwas a rare treat when they got to go out. Sometimes it just seemed as thoughthey cohabitated in the same room. He’d fall asleep alone, and she’d wake upalone.Maybe this would help prevent them from drifting apart, he thoughtoptimistically. Of course, if they did drift apart it would solve the problemof keeping part of his life from the woman he loved, his mind countered.Pushing the thought from his mind, he tried to remain positive. He lovedAlyssa, just as he loved being a garou (werewolf). If he had to keep the twoseparate, it was a small price to pay.Brian was a pure bred, as were all of his packmates. The difference betweenother lycanthropes and a pure bred were simple. A pure bred was born that wayand changed during the late stages of puberty, while an infected lycan changedafter surviving an attack. Since lycanthropy, like vampirism, was kept out ofmainstream science, the exact method of transmission was unknown. Although itwas known that only an attack would spread the disease, it wasn’t transmittedsexually or by blood.Asides from having to keep such a large part of his life a secret, he wascontent. It was an extremely delicate balance, but he believed he had the actdown fairly well.Calling a Brazilian steak house, the Rodizio Grill, he reserved a table underhis full name, Brian Craft. Finished with that he turned up the stereo. Histhoughts elsewhere, his eyes barely registered the sun soaked scenery as itflew by,While garou had more longevity than humans, they were by no means immortal,like vampires. Being twenty-five Brian was just a pup. Thanks to lycan’s sloweraging, he barely looked twenty. Most people who met him and his fiancé thoughtshe was the older of the two, and she was only twenty-two.They had been dating for five years, living together the past three. After hisfather had died when he was eighteen, she had been the only one who could calmhis ensuing rage at the world. For two years he’d blown off her obviousconcern, trying to drown his pain in drugs, alcohol, and violence. Being agarou, drugs and alcohol didn’t work as well as it did for humans. Plus, whenyou can heal broken bones in the space of ten minutes, it was hard to haveenough pain inflicted upon him to mask the emotional distress he had felt.Two years of her unwavering attention while he watched her mature into abeautiful young woman had done its damage. Unwittingly, he had becomeenraptured with her, despite his attempts to ignore her. Once theirrelationship had started, it had matured slowly.The more he thought about it, the fact that it wasn’t a whirlwind of arelationship is probably what had helped hold it together. While most of theirfriends had loved and lost, their emotional bond had only grown stronger. He’dhave thought that spending too much time together would be their downfall, butnow the reverse worried him.Pulling the green muscle car off of Clark road, he made a right onto ColonialStreet. Passing the single story houses with their bright green, well keptyards, he pressed the garage door opener attached to the sun visor. The dooropened before he came to the stop sign where Colonial met Williamsburg Streetand ended. Driving the Chevelle through the slight jog to the left and up thedriveway, he parked next to Alyssa’s white 2008 Mustang GT.Pushing the garage door opener, he killed the large engine. He got out of thecar, walking past the white washer and dryer and up the three steps to the doorleading inside. Standing momentarily, he listened at the door. He could hearmusic playing and the sound, barely audible even to his extraordinary hearing,of pencil tip moving against paper.Opening the door, he walked into the entryway and removed his shoes. Theentryway was covered in white wallpaper with floral designs on it, a largemirror between the front and garage doors, the floor was polished hardwood. Itwrapped around to the right to meet the front door, a small white wooden dooredcloset to the left. The wall between the living room and entryway was onlyseven feet high and didn’t extend to the ceiling. An open four foot rectanglecut into the wall connected the two instead of a door.The living room was painted white, the carpet beige. Three of Alyssa’spaintings adorned the walls. There was also a forty-eight inch flat screen TVon a stand that held all the audio\visual electronics in it, a large beige pitgroup, and a wooden coffee table with four glass inserts in the top. Two thirdsof the length of the room back, the carpet ended and the off white tile of thedining room began.Centered to the breakfast bar, cut into the wall separating the kitchen anddining room, sat a brass and glass table with four black and brass chairs.Alyssa sat in the chair that faced the kitchen, with her back to the frontdoor, and prismacolored drawings spread over the table around her. Her longblonde hair was braided in pigtails and swung as she turned to look over hershoulder. She was dressed in an old GWAR shirt of Brian’s and a pair of rippedblue jeans, her feet bare.He could smell a faint tinge of fear on the air, mingling with her scent. Asshe saw him approach, a flitter of relief played across her face. “Hi babe, didyou forget something?” She asked.“No, something came up, so the meeting is cancelled.” He bent down and kissed herforehead. Standing erect, he looked into her vivid blue eyes. “So I madereservations at Rodizio’s for us.”“Have you done something I should know about?” She teased him, smiling goodnaturedly.The smile was infectious, and his face split into one. “No, little girl. I justthought we should take advantage of tonight.”“Sounds great. How long until we’re supposed to be there?”“Well, just in case you were doing something, I made the reservations for eightforty-five.”“Silly boy, you know I don’t have anything going on. It’s the beginning of myweekend.”“Hey, I never know. With my luck you’d have been out with friends till eight ifI’d made the reservations for seven thirty. Plus, I wanted to get a workout inwhile I have a chance.”Standing up, she gave him a hug. “Thanks, babe.”“For what?” he asked with an arched brow.“For being a loving, thoughtful boyfriend, and a little dense.” She winked athim surreptitiously.He gave her a quick kiss. “Thanks, I think.” Leaving her to her artwork, hewalked back through the living room and down the hallway to the right. Thehallway led to the weight room, guestroom and guest bathroom.Entering the second door on the right, he pulled off his polo shirt and khakisand put on the Miami Heat basketball shorts lying on the floor. Tossing theclothes in a pile by the door, he found the I-pod he kept in the room andinserted the ear pieces, putting the little machine on random. Lying down onthe cool vinyl bench, he brought the barbell up off the stand. As Ministry beganblaring in his ears he started to bench press the two hundred pounds he washolding.Thankfully the altered healing factor of lycanthropes made it really difficultto blow up like Conan-era Arnold. It allowed them to gain tremendous strengthwithout getting a huge physique. Although it took a conscious effort to have asoft touch, he thought as he pushed up another rep.After about fifteen reps he began to sweat a little, showing no other signs ofexertion. His breathing was timed to the reps, but he wasn’t huffing orpanting. Even his face appeared relaxed as his mind continued to run amok.The only things that a lycanthrope’s healing factor couldn’t deal with quicklywere wounds caused by other lycan’s claws or teeth while in wereform, silver,and vampiric bites or claw wounds. It caused one to have a lower regard forpersonal safety. Although, normal bullets and blades could still kill a lycanif the head could be severed completely off, the brain destroyed or the lycanbled to death.Of course, there was another side to all of it. You couldn’t just take a bulletto the chest in front of witnesses and walk away nonchalantly. There was acovenant that most lycans and vampires adhered to. Basically it said that allthe supernatural dirt had to be done out of the public eye. Also, they couldnever reveal themselves to humans, not even family.Brian almost laughed at the thought. Yeah, hey guys, sorry to inform you, butyour bloodline is tainted with a disease that only shows up once every couplethousand births. Oh, and I have it. Yeah, it makes me change into the wolfman.No seriously.The downside was that he would never be able to tell Alyssa about it. He’d haveto cringe in mock fear if some punk ever pulled a gun on them. When what he’dreally want to do is stomp a hole in him. Then again it was all conjecture.Point was, he would always be lying. He couldn’t stop being a garou, and hewouldn’t give up Alyssa. No matter how much nay saying they had done.He could still remember when the little fourteen year old punk girl hit thescene in Sarasota. Little did he realize, he’d later think of the event asdivine intervention. She had just moved with her parents from Kingman, Az. Forreasons he still couldn’t fathom, she had been drawn to him like a moth to flame.Not the typical teenager in anyway, he had fended off the young girlsinexplicable attraction to him, while his friends his age had dated girls asyoung as her or younger. As much as he’d blown her off, she had blown hisfriends off twice as much, he thought with a rueful smile. Guess that provesshe wasn’t like other girls her age. Most of them were so starved for affectionthat they weren’t without a boyfriend for more than a couple days at a time.Then his father had succumbed to cancer, and Brian got a glimpse of what hisfuture was to be like. Living longer than his human counterparts, he would beforced to watch everyone he knew or loved die. Lo and behold, the young Brianhad rebelled. It was funny, no amount of normal teenage angst could cause saidrebellion. Life had been too new and full of surprises. He’d only found out hewas a garou two and a half years before it happened.He’d quickly gained the reputation of being a quick tempered, heavy drinking,drug gobbling badass. He rarely lost a fight, even when he was jumped. As faras he was concerned the covenant could be damned. The only beatings he tookwere administered by his packmates.Jonathon had especially taken offense to his attitude. Of his two packenforcers, Matt had been the more sympathetic. His “lessons” had been gearedmore towards future conflict, while Jack’s (the other pack enforcer) andJonathon’s had been straight punishment, meant as an attitude adjustments.Yet none of that could dent the huge amount of rage he’d felt, nothing but onelittle seventeen year old girl. He could still remember that fateful eveningwith crystal clarity.It had been a weekend night towards the end of summer. Brian had been aimlesssince graduation two years prior. His employment by Jonathon was wearing thin.More often than not, he found himself getting a lesson from one or more of hispackmates instead of actually working at the warehouse. So, in typical weekendfashion, he found himself at the Blue Parrot bar catching a punk show andblowing off steam.The Parrot was a great venue that had closed down later. It’d had all agesshows and served alcohol. People usually had to go north to Tampa-St. Pete tofind that. The only drawback of the bar was its tiny layout. It was only twentyfeet across and eighty feet back, not including the backstage area. Coming fromthe front door, about forty feet of space was taken up by tables and the barthat ran along the wall to the right. Behind the bar, stairs ran up to thesecond floor that over looked the bar and was filled with couches and littletables.The stage only took up twelve feet and was elevated just a few inches above thefloor. The rest of the space was taken up by the pit area which had two supportbeams in it. The two foot across square concrete posts had been known to behazardous to people’s health, especially when the pit was rambunctious, as itwas on this evening. Brian manhandled his way through it, bouncing off peopleand slamming others at random.He had discovered that lsd was one of the only drugs his souped up metabolismcouldn’t pump out quickly, so he’d eaten a few hits on top of a lot ofJagermeister and a bit of nose candy. The aggressive tempo of the music wasbringing him closer and closer to a frenzy.Towards the end of the song, he began to batter the other people in the pit. Awell placed punch here, an elbow there, shoulder check that guy into a supportpost, and rebound with an elbow to some guys face. He flew around, concentratedmayhem on a destruction mission.Walking out of the pit to the bar when the song ended, he ordered a Bud Litedraft. Upending the glass, he slammed the beer before leaving the empty mug onthe bar and sauntering outside. In contrast to the stifling club filled withhot, sweaty bodies, the night air was crisp and refreshing, with a slightchill.Greedily, he sucked in large gulps of fresh air. There was a motley collectionof punks, skins, and scenesters hanging around the entrance and the benchlocated on the side walk by the road. He nodded to a group of his old friendsthat included Alyssa.Her hair was dyed orange with black tips that night. She had let it down foronce. Wearing white knee high stockings with short oxblood Doc Martin boots, aplaid skirt and a black Against All Authority tank top, she was quite afetching sight. She stared him in the eyes, unnerving him slightly.It wasn’t that she wasn’t attractive, or that he had a problem approachingwomen, he just didn’t see her in that light yet. All he was after was theconquests. Although he wouldn’t admit it, he cared for her too much to use anddiscard her. Plus, she was immature compared to the women he went after. Hisnew found confidence had given him access to older women, including thebartender that was serving him even though he was underage.Watching the faces of the young kids around him distort and melt, he didn’t payattention as four guys came out of the bar behind him. Their voices floating upfrom the doorway also didn’t register with his acid soaked mind.“Is that the asshole from the pit?”“Yeah, that’s him.”“Hey! You!” The yelling caused him to turn around, a fist caused him to spinback. Having been sucker punched brought him out of his stupor and straightinto attack mode. He was like a pitbull that had been fed black powder.Landing a solid hook to his attacker, he knocked out the first of the four.Before the guy could hit the sidewalk, Brian followed up with a straight rightinto the guy’s nose, adding insult to injury.Out of his peripheral vision, he saw one of his old friends, Cory, stalking theother three. His hand was about to go into the pocket of his leather jacket,where Brian knew he carried brass knuckles. The thought that someone was goingto try to save him made him smile.“Cory, don’t. I’ve got this,” he said, still smiling maniacally.His friend stared at him incredulously, shrugging. The mixture of the lunaticgrin, the confidence he exuded, and the fact he’d just called off the only helphe had caused the remaining three attackers to hesitate.Jumping on the opportunity, Brian slammed an elbow into the jaw of the attackerclosest to him. He went down in a heap, and Brian heard the sound of Mariocollecting a gold coin in the video game Super Mario Bros. Before the next guycould lift his arms, his face had already been stuffed with three quick,powerful punches. With every hit, the coin sound played in Brian’s head.The last guy standing had gathered the presence of mind to run. The smell ofhis fear excited Brian even more. Before the poor guy could run a dozen steps,he was spun around and headbutted viciously, twice.Brian lost it. He began screaming as he held up his slack body with one hand.The other hand punctuated each word with a brutal punch. “Try to jump me, huh?Who do you think you are? Four on one, huh?” He started slamming his fist intothe jelly that had been the guy’s face with every syllable. “Bad fuckingmistake, asshole.”Lost in the moment, he didn’t hear the diminutive voice behind him. “Brian,please.” But he did feel the hand on his shoulder when she placed it there tostop him.He dropped his victim and spun around, snatching Alyssa up by her neck with onehand. His right hand pistoned back to start battering his newest target. Hisface was twisted in a mask of hatred and rage.His mind recoiled at the fear, compassion, worry, and love etched on the faceof the beautiful girl he was about to pound into a bloody mess of broken boneand flesh. Everything stopped, and the walls of hate and rage he had builtaround the grief for his father came crashing down.Letting go of her, a single tear ran from his eye. His acid soaked brain beganto make connections. He had never truly grieved for his father, just covered itup. He actually loved the little girl in front of him, and she really, trulyloved him.Turning off his memories, he set the bar back on its stand with a mighty heave.Although the memories were a great motivator when working out, that part alwaysdrained him. He laid there, his sweat turning cool, as he felt the torn musclesrepairing themselves.After a couple of minutes, he got up and started doing military benches,reminiscing again. He thought of how happy the pack had been when he finallycame around. Until they found out the reason, that was.Smiling, he wondered why, when everything they had said to him to calm him hadbounced right off, they suddenly thought their advice would stick. None of themunderstood why he choose would the hassle of a permanent human mate. Jonathonwas convinced he would betray the covenant at first. Matt continually extolledthe virtues of a garou mate. Which he would, being mated to Sarah, who wasanother packmate. At the time she was the only other female in the pack.Over the years they had grown to know and accept her. Jonathon was the soleholdout, but it didn’t seem to matter that the owner of a business was aloofaround his manager’s fiancé. Matt and Sarah had become their best friends, asfar as couples were concerned. There were still the occasional propheticdoomsday comments, but Brian thought they had decided to let him live his ownlife.Lifting the small forty pound dumbbell over his head for the umpteenth time, heruminated that it was probably a lot easier not trying to tell him how to livenow that he’d quit being such a jerk. Plus there weren’t many possiblerepercussions for the pack. He was only messing up his own life.Her family had actually put up more of a fight than his pack had. To them,Brian had no future, or at least not one good enough for Alyssa. It hadn’thelped that his reputation preceded him to the point where both her youngersisters and older brother knew of him, none of it good. He’d even had toswallow his pride and not retaliate when her brother had sucker punched him.In his opinion, they still didn’t believe he was good enough for her, but atleast they had quit trying to pull them apart. It probably had a lot to do withher blowing them off after the incident with her brother. Brian still feltpride at the amount of self restraint he had shown that day. He knew Alyssa wasvery proud that he had kept his cool. His relationship with her brother, Josh,was barely amicable to this day.Where once he had felt nothing could come between them, now budding seeds ofdoubt began to bloom. While his rational mind knew it was only the amount oftime spent apart, he couldn’t quell the feeling of unease he’d begun to have.As soon as he had let any doubt in, it had begun to eat at him.Well hopefully tonight will help put some of that to rest, he thought. It wasdefinitely good luck that had brought him this opportunity. He knew he shouldjust blow off the irrational thoughts, but it was more easily said than done.He blew out a heavy sigh, pumping out three more reps before changing exercisesagain.As he started doing single curls, alternating hands, he tried to clear hismind. Dwelling on the subject just gave it more sustenance, which was the lastthing he needed to do. Instead, he focused on the music pouring into his ears.Timing his reps to coincide with the rhythm, he zoned out.Finishing up, he replaced all the weights and the I-pod to their prearrangedspots. Leaving the room, he switched off the lights. He strode into the livingroom on his way to the master bedroom. Alyssa was hunched over one of herdrawings, lost to the world, her colored pencil a blur. Other drawings stilllay on the glass dining room table, an arch of art around her.The picture she was working on reminded Brian of a bad acid trip. It was one ofher few darker pieces, an expedition into her subconscious. It was kind ofpost-apocalyptic; a burnt, melted cityscape with half decomposed bodies lyingin the street that made up the foreground.Even with that subject, the picture had beauty. The sky was a pink and purplesunset. The colors reflected off the towering lumps of melted glass that hadonce been skyscrapers. Plus, he noted, the detail was amazing.The door to the master bedroom was off the dining room. Moving stealthily, heretreated through it and closed the door softly. He didn’t want to ruin herconcentration. Stripping off the shorts he went straight for the masterbathroom. Padding over cool tile, he moved quietly to the shower and turned iton. Stepping into the small room of a shower, he let the water sluice the sweatand dirt from his body. He luxuriated in the hot spray.Chapter twoThe dinner had gone well, and Brian was looking forward to taking his fiancéhome. He could tell from her scent and body language that she was anticipatingwhat would follow when they got there.Walking out of the Rodizio Grill, Brian caught the faint scent of an unfamiliargarou in werewolf form. He didn’t even recognize the garou’s bloodline, butcould tell it wasn’t an Alpha or a pure bred. Inhaling deeply through his nose,he could tell the garou was actually a fair distance away. He realized that ifthe balmy wind hadn’t been from the southwest, he would never have caught thescent.“You alright, babe?” Alyssa asked looking at him with a puzzled expression onher beautiful face, her head cocked slightly to one side. Brian looked downthen swept his gaze up from her black stiletto heels, over the creamy expanseof leg, over the small black cocktail dress that clung to her body. He tried toimprint the picture to his memory, knowing he couldn’t stay with her now.“Sorry, baby. I’ve got a lot of shit on my mind. I think it’d be better if Iwalk back to the house. Just to clear my head.” Although lying to her wasalmost painful, he could see no way around it. This part of his life wouldalways be a secret.“What’s wrong?” She stepped closer to him, the scent of her perfume mingledwith the unique musk that was all her own and filled his nostrils.“It’s just from shit from work. I’m sorry, baby, but I won’t be worth a damntill I figure this out. I’m still coming home, I promise. I just need this.” Hedidn’t know what else to say, and he was afraid if he waited much longer, he’dlose the scent.Leveling her head and frowning slightly, she answered, “If you say so. Try notto be too long, ok?”Nodding, Brian watched her walk to her Mustang, his eyes fixated on her assthrough the thin material of her dress. For a split second he forgot about theother garou, but he caught the faint scent once again on the humid night air.He cursed the sacrifices he was sometimes forced to make, turning and walkingaway as Alyssa got into her car.Once out of her sight, he moved quickly. Leaving the Gulf Gate businessdistrict, he started passing one story suburban homes. Reaching into the grayslacks he realized he had left his cell phone at home. While it was a fortunatemistake if Alyssa tried to call him, it meant he couldn’t inform his packmates.He was going in solo. Nearing the garou’s location, he began searching for adeserted house or yard. His hazel eyes lit upon a for sale sign a couple housesdown.Walking down the street, he watched the houses and yards for any sign of beingwatched. He saw no one, and the little white house appeared vacant. Walkingtowards up the concrete drive, he sniffed the air. He was still downwind of thegarou and there were no canines in the vicinity.Some dogs acted weird around garou in human form, although most werefrightened. When a dog was around a garou changing shape, they went nuts. Itwas the kind of attention he had to avoid.He hurdled the three foot chain link fence without breaking stride, dartinginto the shadows. Once in the shelter of the dark backyard, he strippedquickly. Folding the grey slacks, black button up shirt and boxers, he put themon top of his shoes on the small wooden deck.Taking a deep breath, he forced himself to change. His back arched as painripped through him. His five foot eleven inch frame began to grow, light brownfur rippling over his body. There was an audible crack as his facial bonesshifted to allow a snout to flow forward. Two more followed as his knees poppedbackwards. Moonlight glinted off of his teeth as they grew past his lips, atwisted grimace on his flowing face. Thirty seconds after the change hadstarted, it was over. He breathed a sigh of relief as the pain receded.He bounded over the fence and into drainage ditch, running towards where thescent originated from. He let himself go, tearing through palmetto bushes,reveling in the physical sensations of his muscles uncoiling and the wind inhis fur.Seemingly no sooner than he had started to run, he was behind the house thegarou was in, looking through the back sliding glass door. Seeing no movementinside the living room, he used his advanced senses to try and ascertain whatwas going on. His pulse quickened as he scented fear and blood. A low moan ofanguish was barely audible.He launched himself though the glass door, avoiding the white leather furnitureand little wooden coffee table. Landing on the thick white shag carpeting, herolled to his feet and ran into the short hallway to the right. The second dooron the left was slightly ajar, the assaulting stench of fear, anguish, andhuman blood wafting from it.Bounding towards the door, he stopped two feet from it and pushed it opengently, beware of a trap. Rage boiled inside of him at the sight that greetedhis eyes.It was apparent that the huge black garou hadn’t heard the glass breaking; hewas so intent on ravaging his victim. Splatters of blood randomly sprayed thewhite walls and ceiling crimson. The large beast had its claws and teeth sunkinto the body on the brass frame bed. Sheets black with blood dripped onto thecarpet staining it red.Brian launched himself at the beast’s bared back, taking advantage of hisopponent’s inattention. He clamped his teeth into its right shoulder, sinkinghis claws into the left shoulder and right bicep. The huge size of the garouwas even more apparent once he was latched on. Brian’s rear claws were two feetoff the ground, tearing at the back of his adversary’s legs as he scrambled tofind some grip. He flexed his jaw muscles, trying to shatter the huge beast’scollarbone or separate it’s rotator cuff.His opponent reacted, seizing him by the neck and flinging him across the room.The action caused Brian to rip chunks from the garou’s shoulders. Brian flewinto the stained cedar dresser opposite the door to the hall. The force of theimpact drove the dresser into the drywall breaking it and cracking the studsbehind it.Jumping up, Brain faced the huge black beast. Blood ran from both shouldersmatting the fur. The right shoulder and arm were worse wounds than the leftshoulder, but none of the wounds seemed like enough to even slow his opponentdown. Brian spit the mouthful of flesh and fur on the carpet. Doing so was aninsult by garou customs. Basically, he just said he had no respect and nothingto fear from him. As his adversary came around the bed between them, Brianimproved his stance, settling his weight on the balls of his feet.In a blur of superhuman speed the massive black beast rushed him, swingingwildly. Brian ducked under a right and sidestepped. He raked his claws acrossits abdomen, opening four wounds. The garou whirled, cracking him in the sideof the head with a spinning back fist.His adversary tried to press the advantage, throwing a powerful right haymaker.Ducking underneath, he stepped closer to the garou, smothering its power. Heslammed a left elbow into its solar plexus, following up with a right elbow tothe snout. Brian was grabbed and tossed into the wall to the right. The garoushook his head to clear it before lunging at Brian again.He hit the wall, bounced to the floor, rolled and came up crouched, whitedrywall dust in his fur. Using his legs to explode forward, he met the garou inthe air. Its momentum was too much to overcome, and they ended up on the floor.Brian was on his back below the beast, barely holding its snapping maw from hisface and neck.Wrapping its hands around Brian’s neck, the garou started squeezing, chokinghim. He moved his hold off the beast so that he was gripping the upper andlower jaws and began to wrench them apart. His adversary grunted and releasedthe strangle hold, allowing Brian to twist around to his hands and knees. Thegarou blasted the back of his head with a flurry of punches, only stopping towrap him in a bear hug as Brian stood up.Pretending to struggle, he jockeyed his left foot behind the beast. Bending hisright knee, he swept his opponents foot forward as he snapped his right legstraight, pushing the garou over on his back and landing on top of it. Theimpact sent the air rushing from the beast’s lungs, causing it to loosen thebear hug. Brian used the slight break to twist around and lunge up, freeing hisarms. Using short quick swipes, he started raking his claws down its face.The beast released the hold of Brian’s abdomen to grab his wrists. Brianlowered his snout and snapped a little chunk of flesh from its chest. Onceagain he spit the mouthful out, this time in its face. Wrestling with the garouhe finally pinned its left arm under his right knee.He began to rain punishment down on his opponent, alternating punches, elbowstrikes, facial slashes, and when no other opening presented itself, he slashedits right shoulder and arm. The massive garou bucked until it freed its arm,spinning to its hands and knees.Brian was ready for this and ran his claws down its back before putting somedistance between them. He watched the beast warily as it whirled around to facehim once again. Blood ran from more than a dozen wounds.He knew the only reason he wasn’t dead yet was because his adversary wasrelying on brute force instead of skill and experience. He also noted that thegarou fought as a human would, not like a werewolf should. He thanked his luckystars the beast wasn’t properly trained.Deciding to play with it a little, he assumed a boxer’s stance and asked, “HeyFido, does your Alpha know you’re attacking humans.” His voice was distortedfrom speaking through a snout, and it was lower due to changed vocal chords.The huge garou gave a throaty laugh. “Stupid pup, this is a recruitment.” Itswung a wild right haymaker.Ducking under the blow, he slammed a right to the body followed by a left hookto its face. The garou stumbled back two steps and threw a left hook. Circlingto his right, Brian caught the punch and blasted a hard jab into its snout.The beast howled in rage, grabbing Brian and tossing him into the wall abovethe dresser once again. Drywall and studs broke as he went into and through thewall, landing on the beige tile of the master bathroom.Rising to his feet, he looked back at the master bedroom through the hole inthe wall. The garou tossed the dresser to the side and kicked the lower part ofthe wall in. Gripping the hole in the wall on either side, it ripped the walldown, enlarging the hole.Brian ripped the porcelain sink from the wall as the beast broke a stud, makingroom for it to fit through. Water gushed from the broken pipes, drenching himas the garou entered the bathroom. Gripping the sink in his left hand hefeinted a strike with it. His adversary went to block and Brian ripped hisright claw across its stomach. He ducked a wild right and smashed the sinkacross its head opening a large gash along the side of it. The chunk of thesink in his right hand protruded about five inches from his closed fist,tapering into a curved point. Brian then had to eat a left hook in order toland an overhand right of his own.Ducking another wild right, he slammed the makeshift porcelain shank into thegarou’s exposed stomach. As Brian sank it into the beast’s stomach again itgrabbed him by his right shoulder with its left hand and slammed a viciousright into his face. He saw a bright flash of white light before the powerfulblow knocked him into a punch drunk daze. His adversary laughed with a deeprumbling sound.Even a little out of it, he knew that he wouldn’t survive if he took many moreof these powerful blows. If he were to be knocked unconscious, the beast couldkill him at its leisure. Watching its right fist as the garou drew back for thenext blow, desperation took hold in Brian. Before the fist could streak towardshim again he jammed the makeshift shank into the underside of the beast’s jaw.It yelped in surprise and Brian opened his hand, slamming his palm into theporcelain to drive it deeper.The garou released its grip and howled in anguish, reaching for it’s woundedsnout with both hands. Brian blasted a right hook into its face then slashed itwith his left claw. Keeping the momentum going he popped two quick jabs intoits wounded snout before catching the chunk of porcelain with a right uppercut.Brian pressed his advantage, slowly walking the garou back, out of thebathroom, hitting it with quick straight strikes. Once he had it backedsufficiently into the master bedroom, he began to circle to his right.Switching from knuckles to claws, he continued his vicious attack. The largegarou bellowed, pulling the chunk of porcelain from its snot. His chest, stomach,and arms were a mess of bleeding slashes.Brian ducked its attempt to imbed the chunk into his face, stepping in andsinking his right claws into its stomach almost to the first knuckle. He didthe same with to the garou’s right calf. Sinking his teeth into its hamstrings,he attempted to hobble the giant.Once again Brian found himself hurtling through the hole in the wall. This timethe impact cracked drywall, cinderblock, and shattered the mirror above wherethe sink had been. He landed in a puddle, water cascading onto him.He pushed himself to his feet, spitting the newest chunk of flesh onto the wettiles. Peering through ten hole, he expected the huge garou to follow him intothe bathroom, Instead the bedroom was abandoned, the door to the hall stillswinging.Brian shook himself, spraying the bathroom with the water in his fur beforebounding after his opponent. He stayed low, running on all fours to avoid anypossible ambushes. Not spotting his prey in the hall, he ran into the livingroom. As he rounded the corner, he found the coffee table sailing through theair at him.He took the impact on his forearms, deflecting the table to the left, rising,his arms raised to block the next attack. Once his line of sight was clear offlying furniture, he saw the large garou disappear into the drainage ditch.He started towards the broken sliding glass door to follow before thinkingbetter of it. He padded back into the bedroom, creeping up to the bed. Thebloody mess on the bed was still breathing. Walking back into the living room,he searched until he found a Thrasher magazine with the address on it. Findinga phone in the kitchen, he dialed a number from memory. It took two attempts ofhitting the buttons with his claws.“Hello?’ A female answered.“Hey Sarah, can I yell at Matt? It’s Brian.”“Umm, yeah, just a sec,” she said, puzzlement evident in her voice.After a couple moments Matt came on the line. “Hey bro, what’s up?”“Sorry to bother you, but I have a problem. I need you to come to…” Brianlooked at the address and recited it.“OK, what’s goin on?”“I’ve got an attack survivor. I fought off the garou, and I need you to lookafter this kid.”“Fuck. Did you tell Jonathon?”“Nope. I was hoping you could fill him in. I’m on this guy’s landline, and Jonathonwould kill me if I called his phone,” Brian explained.“Yeah, you’ve gotta point. I’ll be there as soon as possible.”“Thanks.” The line was already dead.He crept warily back into the bedroom, surveying the extent of the damage tothe person in the bloody bed. The victim was severely ravaged most of themuscle and flesh of the right leg was gone. Both of his forearms, chest, face,and left bicep were also torn asunder. Checking the victim’s vitals, Brianrealized two things in quick succession. First, the victim was male. The secondrealization was that the guy had fallen into a lycanthropic healing coma, andthe wounds were already beginning to close.Brian didn’t know much about infected victims, but it didn’t seem normal forsomeone so recently infected to be able to enter a healing sleep already. Heshook his head. Keeping his senses alert for the return of his opponent, hebegan to clean up.He wrapped the young male’s worst wounds with what little bedding wasn’talready soaked in blood. Once the guy was situated as well as could be, hewaded through the destruction of the bathroom. Finding the water shut offvalve, he stopped the water cascading onto the tiles. Searching the small roomfor garbage bags, he came up empty.Checking on the victim, he found the kid’s pulse stronger, his breathing lessshallow and irregular. Satisfied the kid would be alright, he proceedingthrough the house to the kitchen. He stopped in the living room, taking in adeep breath of warm night air coming in through the broken sliding glass door.There was no trace of any garou scents.Rifling through drawers and cabinets, he came upon some hefty bags. He carriedhis find back into the bedroom, remaining in were form incase the garou fromearlier came back. Since he had no weapons, it seemed like the best idea.Gathering the bloody remains of the bedding, he bagged it. Using his claws, hecut the blood soaked carpet. Shouldering the bed out of his way, he collectedthe carpet scraps and bagged them also. Finished with that, he looked about forthe porcelain shank from earlier. After an exhaustive search of the bed andbath rooms came up with nothing, he broadened his search to the other rooms. Hefinally located the chunk in the living room, lying on the carpet by the couch.He was about to go back into the bed room when he caught the sound of an enginecoming down the quiet suburban street. The noise grew closer, headlightslighting the room as the vehicle swung into the drive.Brian bounded to the window, using one claw to raise a blind. He was rewardedwith the sight of Matt’s battered grey Silverado running in the drive. Thewiry, brown skinned male in his apparent mid twenties was Brian’s packmate.Matt ran his hand over his short cropped black hair, sniffing the air. He wasdressed as usual in climbing boots, jeans, and a black t-shirtBrian realized he’d been holding his breath and released it. He unlocked thefront door then moved back out of view as Matt walked up. In the pack hierarchyhe was immediately above Brian, and was his closest confidant.“Come in.” Brian said in a normal volume. Matt walked in, quickly shutting thedoor. Brian continued, “Sorry to interrupt your evening.’Matt cracked his trademark, devil may cry smile. “Don’t worry about it, got meout of the house.”“Please tell me you brought some firepower?”“Of course,” Matt replied, pulling a Desert Eagle .357 from the waist band ofhis jeans.Brian’s were form rippled as the fur retracted into the body as it shrank backto human. His naked body was completely clean. Even the scent of the otherGarou was gone. Taking the pistol from Matt, he hefted the reassuring weight,smiling. His left hand still held the chunk of porcelain.Matt’s smile never faltered. “So what the fuck happened?’Shaking his head, Brian began his summary. While he related the story, he ledMatt back into the bedroom. Matt’s brown eyes quickly took in the scene,darting over the damage to the room, the two black trash bags, and settling onthe victim’s still form. As the two moved closer to the bed, Matt’s smilefaded.“The damage was worse. He’s fallen into a regenerative coma,” Brian observed.“Fuck,” Matt said with a shrug of his shoulders, “it’s better than a body.Still, Jonathon is going to be pissed.”Brian pulled his gaze from the young male’s slowly healing wounds, looking upinto Matt’s face. “Did you talk to him?”Matt’s smile returned. “Left that for Sarah. You want to talk about pissed.”“Shit, so you don’t know what the plan is?”\“I talked to her on the way over. I’m taking our friend here to Carlos’s house.We’re all meeting up at the warehouse early in the morning. I guess Josh hadsome bad news.”“Yeah, I bet it has something to do with this. And what the fuck is early?”“Around six. What time do you start opening?”“Seven, so that should be fine. How do you want to do this?” Brian motioned tothe inert body they were standing next to.“Fuck, I wish Jonathon was here.” Matt paused before starting back up. “Wraphim in a blanket, toss him in the cab. I guess.”“You mind doing that while I find some clothes and pack him a bag?”“No problem.” Matt started searching for a comforter, Brian having alreadybagged the bloody one.
He walked through the debris back into thebedroom, wiping his feet on the carpet to clean them off. Matt was rolling thebody in a green comforter, while Brian scoured the closet. Finding an old gymbag, he filled it with clothes.Selecting a pair of ripped jeans that would fit his waist and an old flannelshirt, he put them on. He stuffed the .357 into the waistband and rolled up theexcess of the long jeans. He then slipped on a pair of Nike’s that were toolarge for him, tossing a newer pair in the bag.Shouldering the gym bag, he snatched up the two garbage bags and strode out ofthe house. Matt cradled the blanket swathed young man and followed. Briantossed the bags into the truck, while Matt stuck the motionless body into thecab.Matt closed the passenger door softly. “You need a ride?”“No, I still have to get my clothes and change back.”Matt chuckled, “Guess I’ll see you in the morning.”“Thanks again.”Watching Matt drive down the street, Brian looked for signs some concernedcitizen had witnessed the scene. It seemed as nothing was amiss, so he turnedand walked back through the still open front door.Doing a thorough scan of the house, he made sure to leave no signs but thedamage done to the house. He found three chunks of meat, now furless, andtossed them in a garbage bag. Since the only way back to his clothes that heknew went through the drainage ditch, he left that way.As he picked his way through the palmetto bushes crowding the ditch, he kepthis right hand on the butt of the Desert Eagle. Although he couldn’t smell, seeor otherwise sense any enemies, he thought it wise to err on the side ofcaution.He effortlessly jumped the chain link fence, back into the yard were he’d lefthis clothes. Tossing the clothes he was wearing in a pile, he stripped in thelight of a half full moon. At least there is some time before the next fullmoon, he thought. He finished dressing, his mind going over all thedifficulties the pack was in for because of this. Picking up the gun andclothes, he tossed the clothes into the garbage bag with chunks of meat. Hetucked the pistol into the grey slacks.Starting back towards the street, he pushed the thoughts from his mind. He kepta constant vigil for any sign of an ambush, scenting the air. His right thumbwas hooked in his slack pocket, keeping the hand close to the pistol. He tossedthe garbage bag into a can left by the street a few houses down, walking backto his house

story:
Short Summary

Four dear friends spent the past year writing, cultivating and materializing a book titled E//O. E//O is a contemporary poetic retelling of the Eurydice and Orpheus myth—a memory of a memory of a memory. Following the classical story of love, death, and a trip to the beyond to rescue love, our E//O examines Eurydice’s under-examined perspective. What motivates her to leave the world of the living and keeps her in Hades? E//O traces our own lives as we struggle to find meaning and love in a cold dark world.


What We Need & What You Get


In order to concretize our dreams, we REALLY NEED YOUR HELP! We’re fundraising for TWO MONTHS (Until AUG 1st! ). We’re looking to meet the GOAL OF RAISING $2500 in order to cover our material costs, and help pay us back for the actual tears, sweat and blood that went into this book.

GOAL TO MEET BY AUGUST: $2500

The best part of you helping us out is that you will get this beautifully detailed book, posters, custom poems and more, in your mailbox!  

If you donate $10 an AMAZING ACCOMPANYING DOWNLOADABLE CD OF ORIGINAL MUSIC made by our friends. The CD also tells the story of Eurydice and Orpheus as well, and the perfect companion to the book! 

If you donate $25, you get an incredible tragic BOOK along with the CD!

If you donate $50, you get a BOOK, a CD, and an INCREDIBLE HAND-PRINTED POSTER designed by the stunning artist, Lauren Moran, who gave life and intensity to the poems in our book!  

But there really is no gift too low or too high. $5 will help cover our material costs, and a gift of $100 would enable us to be able to take this book on a reading tour! (Hopefully to a city near you!)

   

The Impact

Old myths of love, of war, and of love as war resonate with our lives and compel us to examine our own drives towards living, and not. Just turn to Anne Carson, Théâtre du Soleil, Louise Glück or Orfeu Negro to understand the power of the classics that has taken artists across mediums towards their adaptation. This is by no means our first dabbling with the Greeks. Suzahn is constantly engaged in the tragic as a mode of analysis, creation and living and Louis’ undergraduate directing thesis was a politically charged contemporary adaption of the Oresteia. 

PROCESS

This was an attempt at decentralized and rhizomatic collective-creation. It was no easy effort to transcend time and space to accomplish what we set out to do on a deadline. 

E//O Collaborators:

Text: Louis Jargow, Suzahn Ebrahimian

Images and Posters: Lauren Moran

Design: Blaine O'Neill

Publishing:  Patrick Kiley (Publication Studio Hudson) 

Original Music: Jesse Alexander Vinicor (Sleepers Bells), Jenn Grossman, Alex Beaulieu (The Miami), Calum McPherson Smith, Suzahn Ebrahimian and Louis Jargow.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on Facebook, check our out Soundcloud and get your family and friends pumped!~

https://www.facebook.com/eandorfu?ref=hl

https://soundcloud.com/louis-jargow/sets/e-o
